A city licensee that meets the qualification of subsection (a) above may apply with the city clerk's office to become an art and entertainment district permittee by filling out a form provided by the city which shall include a copy of the commercially printed name and/or logo to be used on the cups that the licensee shall provide for off premise consumption. The city clerk may deny a permit if the applicant does not meet the qualifications stated in subsection (a) above. The applicant may appeal the denial of the application for a permit to the city council by filing a written notice of appeal with the city clerk within fifteen (15) days after the denial. A permit shall be valid for a license year at the end of which a renewal application must be made. 
(c)  Action against permit . A permit may be revoked, suspended or not renewed by the city clerk if the permittee or applicant for renewal no longer meets the qualifications stated in subsection (a) above. The permittee or applicant for renewal may appeal the adverse decision of the city clerk to the city council by filing a written notice of appeal with the city clerk within fifteen (15) days after the adverse action. 
(Ord. No. 1047, § 8, 11-4-13)  
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 816, adopted October 18, 1999, amended chapter 4 entirety. 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 3-5-14, 3-7-13, 11-47-110; cruelty to animals, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-14. 
 
ARTICLE I. - DEFINITIONS; AUTHORITY; PENALTIES AND FEES 
 
Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
The following words and terms, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
Animal shall mean any organism of the kingdom Animalia other that a human being; especially a mammal, fish, bird or reptile. 
Animal control center shall mean the place or places designated or used as such by the city for a place of confinement for animals held under the authority of this chapter. 
Animal control officers shall mean the director and all enforcement officers assigned to the animal control department. 
At large shall mean any animal off the property of its owner or person-in-charge and not carried by such person, or kept in an effective enclosure, or under control by means of a leash, cord, chain, or otherwise. 
Bitten Seized with the teeth or claws, so that the skin of the person or animal seized has been nipped or gripped, or has been wounded or pierced and includes suspected or confirmed contact of saliva with a break or abrasion of the skin or with any mucous membrane, as determined by a licensed physician. 
Cage shall mean an enclosed humane structure that confines animal(s) and restricts access of other animals. 
Caged shall mean confined in a cage which may include a vehicle, in such a way that the free movement of an animal is restricted so that the caged animal is prevented from biting or attacking a person or animal. 
Canine corps dogs shall mean those members of the canine family maintained by governmental agencies for exclusive use in official duties assigned to those agencies. Seeing eye dogs shall be included within the meaning of this definition. 
Cat shall mean any member of the domestic feline family, three (3) months of age or older. 
Cattery shall mean a duly licensed establishment or structure used for harboring more than four (4) cats that are more than six (6) months old. 
Dog shall mean any member of the domestic canine family, three (3) months of age or older. 
Dog presumed to be vicious shall mean any dog that has bitten or attacked another person or animal. 
Exotic shall mean an exotic or wild animal shall be defined as one which would ordinarily be confined to a zoo, or one which would ordinarily be found in a wilderness of this or any other country; or a species of animal not indigenous to the United States or to North America or which causes zoonotic diseases or one which otherwise causes a reasonable person to be fearful of significant destruction of property or of bodily harm, the latter including, but not limited to, raccoons, bobcats, coyotes, wolves, and other such animals. Wild or exotic animals specifically do not include animals of a species customarily used in Alabama as domestic farm animals, fish confined in an aquarium, birds or insects. 
Has been exposed. Seized with the teeth or claws, so that the skin of the person or animal seized has been nipped or gripped, or has been wounded or pierced and includes suspected or confirmed contact of salvia with a break or abrasion of the skin or with an mucous membrane, as determined by a licensed physician. 
Humane. Characterized by tenderness, compassion and sympathy for animals. 
Humane trap or cage shall mean an enclosure in which an animal can be caught or restrained without causing injury, pain or undue suffering to the animal. 
Immunization against rabies means the injection, in a manner approved by the state health officer and the state veterinarian, of antirabies vaccine to species other than those for which reliable immunization data is available shall be a violation of Act Ala 90-530 of the Legislature of Alabama. 
Keep shall mean confine, harbor and allow to remain. 
Kennel shall mean a duly licensed establishment or structure used for harboring, raising, training or boarding more than four (4) dogs that are more than six (6) months old. 
Kitten shall mean any member of the domestic feline family less than three (3) months of age. 
Nuisance animal means an animal that threatens the safety of or damages a member of the general public or interferes with the ordinary use and enjoyment of other's property. 
Owner shall mean any person having a right of property in the animal, or who keeps or harbors the animal, or who has it in his care, or acts as its custodian, or who permits the animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by him. 
Pen shall mean an enclosure for housing and feeding small animals. 
Person shall mean any individual, partnership, company, corporation or other legal entity. When appropriate, these terms shall mean the singular, plural, masculine, feminine, and neuter. 
Person-in-charge shall mean any person in whose charge the animal is being kept, and all the responsible adult members of the household in which an animal is kept or allowed or suffered to remain. 
Prima facie evidence means at first view or sight. 
Public nuisance shall mean any animal, or any condition resulting from an animal, that unreasonably annoys human beings, endangers the life or health of other animals or persons, or substantially interferes with the rights of citizens, other than its owner, to enjoyment of life or property. 
Puppy shall mean any member of the domestic canine family less than three (3) months of age. 
Quarantine for rabies observation shall mean confinement under the direct care, custody, control and supervision of a licensed veterinarian chosen by the owner or person-in-charge for a period of ten (10) days subsequent to the date of the exposure, or as otherwise directed by the health officer. 
Rabies officer shall mean a licensed veterinarian or animal control officer appointed by the county board of health and approved by the state health officer and state veterinarian. 
Restraint on premises means an animal is considered to be under restraint if it is confined within the property limits of its owner or person-in-charge. 
Run shall mean enclosed structure that confines animals and restricts access to or from other animals. 
Shelter for outdoor dog shall mean a shelter with a roof, enclosed sides, a doorway and a solid floor that provides protection from the elements. 
Stray animal shall mean any animal running at large, the owner or person-in-charge of which is unknown. 
Vicious animal shall mean any animal that is known to have bitten or attacked a person or other animal without provocation or cause. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-1, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-2. - Office of director of the animal control department established. 
(a)  The office of director of the animal control department is hereby established. The director of the animal control department shall be an officer of the city and shall have the responsibility for the day-to-day supervision of the animal control division of the department of public services. The director of the animal control department shall be appointed by the mayor subject to the approval of the city council as provided by law. The director of the animal control department shall hold office for the term of the mayor making the appointment . The director of the animal control department shall be under the direct supervision and control of the director of the police department. Generally, the director of the animal control department shall be available to council members to respond to requests for information or questions related to matters under the general control of the director of the animal control department which are pertinent to the performance of the council members' duties. 
(b)  Any provisions of this chapter referring to the director shall also mean and include any authorized employee acting in his stead and under his supervision. 
(c)  All law enforcement officers assigned to the Guntersville Police Department shall hereinafter assist the animal control director and officers in the enforcement in any provisions in this ordinance. Any provisions of this chapter referring to the director or animal control officers shall also mean and include any authorized law enforcement officer acting or assisting in his stead and under his supervision. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly and willfully to oppose or resist the Director, any Assistant Director, or Animal Control Officer, in executing or discharging any regular duty, or in any way to interfere with, hinder, or prevent any such officer from discharging his duty. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-2, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-3. - Disposition of fees. 
All monies collected, as provided for in this chapter, shall be turned over and delivered forthwith to the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-3, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-4. - Citations and warrants. 
(1)  Citations 
(a)  When any animal is found by the director or by an animal control officer to be in violation of any provision of this chapter, and the person or persons responsible become known to the director or to an animal control officer, he may issue a citation to the owner or person-in-charge for said violation directing him to appear in the municipal court at a time and a date stated therein to answer to charges of violations of this chapter, and said charges shall be stated in said citation. It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any person to fail to appear in the municipal court at the time and place stated in a citation issued by the director or an animal control officer. 
(2)  Warrants 
(b)  Violations of any provisions of any chapter of this ordinance requiring affidavit made before, and warrant issued by a municipal judge or magistrate of the city shall be serviced by a duly sworn officer of the Guntersville Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 813, § 5-4, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-5. - Minimum penalties. 
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be punished as provided in the general penalty provision of the Code of Ordinances of the City, provided, however, that when any person is found guilty of violating any provision of this chapter for which a fine is provided and imposed, in addition to such other punishment as may be provided by the court, the minimum fines shall apply as follows:

The fines listed above are in addition to all applicable court cost. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-5, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-6. - Habitual offender. 
Any owner or person-in-charge who repeatedly and habitually allows, suffers or permits any animal to unlawfully violate any provision of this article shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) in addition to any current charges or fines. Proof of three (3) violations by the same owner or person-in-charge within a twelve (12) month period shall be prima facie evidence that said owner or person-in-charge is an habitual offender, and the burden of proof shall be upon said owner or person-in charge to prove otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-6, 10-18-99)  
Secs. 4-7—4-10. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DOGS, CATS, AND OTHER ANIMALS IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4-11. - Cruelty to animals prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful if a person: 
(a)  Fails to provide adequate food and water for any animal; or 
(b)  Overworks any animal causing physical pain or suffering; or 
(c)  Beats, tortures, injures, torments, poisons, deprives of necessary sustenance or mutilates any animal, causing physical pain, suffering, or death; or 
(d)  Fails to provide medical treatment for any sick, diseased or injured animal; or 
(e)  Keeps any animal under unsanitary or inhumane conditions which are detrimental to the animal's health and general welfare, or fails to maintain the animal in a condition of good order or cleanliness which increases the probability of transmission of disease; or 
(f)  Teases, molests, baits or harasses any animal; or 
(g)  Sets any rabbit, raccoon, fox or other such animal loose for the purpose of chasing or hunting the animal or conducting a race using such animal; or 
(h)  Promotes, permits, stages, holds, manages, conducts, carries on, or attends any game, exhibition, contest, fight or combat involving one or more animals or involving animals and humans; or 
(i)  Fails to provide adequate shelter for an animal wherein the animal can be protected from the extremes of weather (heat, cold, rain, wind, sun, etc.), provided such person is the owner or person-in-charge of such animal; or 
(j)  Transports or carries any animal in a motor vehicle unless the animal is safely enclosed within the vehicle or protected by a cab or container, cage, cross-teter, or other devise to prevent the animal from falling out of, or being thrown from vehicle; or 
(k)  Places or confines an animal or allows an animal to be placed or confined in a motor vehicle under such conditions or for such a period of time as to endanger the health or welfare of the animal because of temperature, lack of food or water, or such other conditions as may reasonably be expected to cause suffering, disability or death; or 
(l)  Restrains an animal with a leash or humane restraining device that is less than 8 feet long, unless walking or training such animal; 
(m)  Any person who unlawfully or maliciously kills, disables, disfigures or injures any animal, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
Any owner or person-in-charge violating this section shall be guilty of cruelty to animals. Provided, however, that no prosecution shall be commenced and no arrest made pursuant to this section, except upon affidavit made before, and warrant issued by a municipal judge or magistrate of the city. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-11, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-12. - Abandoning animals prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to transport any animal into the city and subsequently abandon or set loose said animal with the intent of avoiding the responsibility for its custody and care. Further, it shall be unlawful for any person to transport any animal out of the city limits and subsequently abandon or set loose said animal with intent of avoiding the responsibility for its custody and care. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-12, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-13. - Public nuisance. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, possess or maintain an animal in such a manner as to constitute a public nuisance. By way of example and not of limitation, the following acts or actions by an owner or person-in-charge of an animal are hereby declared to be a public nuisance and are therefore unlawful: 
(1)  Allowing or permitting an animal to damage the property of anyone other than its owner, including but not limited to, getting into or turning over garbage containers, or damaging gardens, flowers and vegetables, or defecating upon the property of another. 
(2)  Maintaining an animal that habitually or repeatedly chases, snaps at, attacks, or barks at pedestrians, joggers, bicycles or other vehicles, or animals being walked on leash. 
(b)  Any owner or person-in-charge violating this section shall be guilty of public nuisance animals. Provided, however, that no prosecution shall be commenced and no arrest made pursuant to this section, except upon affidavit made before, and warrant issued by a municipal judge or magistrate of the City. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-13, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-14. - Noisy animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to keep on a residential lot or premises within the city any animal or group of animals, known to said person, to habitually, continuously or intermittently to make or emit sounds or noises of such volume and nature as unreasonably to interfere with or disturb the peace, quiet, comfort and repose of a person or ordinary sensibilities within the neighborhood in the reasonable use and enjoyment of adjacent property. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to keep on any tract, lot or premises within the City any animal or group of animals, whether the same is housed in a cattery, kennel, building or other structure(s), under such circumstances that the sounds or noises emitted by said animals are of such volume and nature as unreasonable to interfere with or disturb the peace, quiet, comfort and repose of persons of ordinary sensibilities in the reasonable use and enjoyment of any adjacent property used for residential purposes. 
Any owner or person-in-charge violating this section shall be guilty of maintaining a nuisance. Provided, however, that no prosecution shall be commenced and no arrest make pursuant to this section, except upon affidavit made before, and warrant issued by a municipal judge or magistrate of the City. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-14, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-15. - Odor from animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to keep on a residential lot or premises within the City any animal or group of animals, known to said person, to habitually, continuously or intermittently to create offensive odors so as to interfere with the reasonable use and enjoyment of adjacent property or neighboring premises. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to keep on any tract, lot or premises within the City any animal or group of animals, whether the same is housed in a cattery, pen, kennel, building or other structure(s), under such circumstances that the odor from same interferes with the reasonable use and enjoyment of adjacent property or neighboring premises. 
Any owner or person-in-charge violating this section shall be guilty of maintaining a nuisance. Provided, however, that no prosecution shall be commenced and no arrest make pursuant to this section, except upon affidavit make before, and warrant issued by a municipal judge or magistrate of the city. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-15, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-16. - Sanitation of premises in which animals are kept. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or person-in-charge to keep or maintain a yard, run, pen or any enclosure in which animals are kept in such an unsanitary condition that the lives, or health of the public generally, of the owner, person-in-charge, his family or the animals contained shall be endangered. This condition will be deemed to exist when the yard, pen or enclosure shows evidence of not being cleaned weekly. The presence in or about such yard, pen, or enclosure of flies, the live larvae of flies, roaches, rats or other vermin or conditions that permit or favor the growth, existence or development of such shall be prima facie evidence of failure to comply with this section. All debris and residue shall be removed weekly and disposed of in a proper and sanitary manner. 
(b)  Any owner or person-in-charge of a pen or enclosure wherein animals are kept shall be required to contain and treat all stormwater runoff from such pen or enclosure so as to meet the pollutant limitations included in the City of Guntersville National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) stormwater permit issued by the Alabama Department of Environmental Management. A retention pond shall be required at such places if containment and treatment of stormwater runoff without a retention pond will result in stormwater discharge that is not within effluent discharge limitations as provided in the city's NPDES permit. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or person-in-charge to keep any animal in the city in any pen any part of which is within twenty (20) feet of a dwelling occupied by a person other than the owner or person-in-charge of said animal. Provided, however, that this section shall not apply to enclosures in which animals kept in publicly owned facilities, not otherwise creating any nuisance and kept under the sanitary conditions of this chapter. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any animal in any pen in the city, unless such pen has a minimum area of fifty (50) square feet for one animal and an additional twenty (20) square feet for each additional animal kept, to every portion of which each an every animal shall have free and unrestricted access. Provided, however, that this section shall not apply to enclosures in which animals kept in publicly owned facilities, not otherwise creating any nuisance and kept under the sanitary conditions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-16, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-17. - Duty to restrain dogs and cats. 
(a)  Dogs . It shall be the duty of every owner or person in charge of a dog to keep said animal on a leash at all times when said animal is present in a public place, including, but not limited to all city parks, with the exception of any specified dog park established by the City of Guntersville and designated as same. Any person who violates any provision herein shall be subject to a fine not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00) and/or imprisonment not exceeding thirty (30) days. Any such violation shall constitute a separate offense on each successive day occurring. 
(b)  Cats. It shall be unlawful for the owner or any person having custody or control of any cat within the city to allow such cat to be a nuisance, cause destruction or damage to the property of another, or to run at large. Provided, however, that no prosecution shall be commenced and no arrest made pursuant to this section except upon affidavit made before and warrant issued by a judge or magistrate of municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-17, 10-18-99; Ord. No. 1054, § 1, 7-21-14)  
Sec. 4-18. - Humane traps. 
(a)  The director or any animal control officer is hereby authorized, in order to apprehend animals in violation of this chapter, which are otherwise difficult to apprehend, to use traps humanely designed to capture said animals by placing the same upon any private property or public property of any person granting permission therefore. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of the director or an animal control officer to check such traps daily and remove captured animals therefrom to an animal control center where they shall be disposed of as otherwise provided herein. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to molest or tamper with any such trap, or to remove any animal captured in any such trap, or to interfere with the director or animal control officer insetting or servicing any such trap. 
(b)  Any owner or person-in-charge of any premises within the city may set an approved humane trap on such premises for the purpose of trapping and removing any animals, except songbirds, which have entered the premises. The owner or person-in-charge must notify the director or an animal control officer prior to setting the trap. Use of any trap pursuant to this section shall be coordinated with the director or an animal control officer to make sure such trapping is conducted at times consistent with the operating hours of an animal control department, it being the intent of this section that no captured animal remain trapped for more than twelve (12) hours. It shall be the duty of the director or animal control officer to check such traps daily and remove captured animals therefrom to the animal control center where they shall be disposed of as otherwise provided herein. 
It shall be a violation of this article for any owner or person-in-charge of any premises to do any of the following: 
(1)  Use any trap to capture or remove songbirds; 
(2)  Use any trap on any premises not his own or not under his charge; 
(3)  Fail to inspect any trap at least every twelve (12) hours; 
(4)  Fail to deliver any animal captured therein to the city animal control department or to the animal's owner, if known, within twelve (12) hours of its entrapment; and if animal's owner is unknown fail to notify the city animal control department within twelve (12) hours of its entrapment; 
(5)  Fail to exercise reasonable care and diligence to avoid injury to the trapped animal; 
(6)  Use, or permit to be used, any leg hold trap or snare. 
Before any person shall be permitted to obtain a humane trap from the Animal Control Department for use on his own premises or over which he is in charge, such person shall sign an agreement that he has been advised that the hereinabove enumerated acts or failures to act constitute a violation of this ordinance. Said agreement shall contain a statement that the owner or person-in-charge of the trap shall hold the City of Guntersville and all employees harmless for any damages or actions that may result from said entrapment. 
(c)  Any owner or person-in-charge of any dog or cat captured in a humane trap that is off the premises of the owner or person-in-charge thereof shall be prima facie presumed to have allowed, suffered or permitted such animal to be or run at large. If, at any time, a dog or cat is captured by use of such trap, and the owner or person-in-charge is known or becomes known to the director or an animal control officer, such owner or person-in-charge shall be given a citation to appear in the municipal court as provided in section 4-5 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-18, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-19. - Chaining of dogs or cats. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to tie or chain an animal in a manner that presents a hazard to themselves, the animal or to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-19, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-20. - Duty of owner to remove overturned or scattered garbage. 
It shall be the duty and unlawful for the owner or person-in-charge of any dog or cat which has been allowed or suffered by said person to run at large, to fail to pick up and remove to the landfill, or to a secure authorized container, any garbage or refuse which said animal has caused to be overturned, spilled or scattered upon any residential lot occupied or unoccupied for human habitation, or upon any right-of-way adjacent thereto, upon demand from the owner or occupant thereof, or upon demand of the director or any animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-20, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-21. - Duty of owner for removal of feces. 
It shall be the duty and unlawful for the owner or person-in-charge of any dog or any cat to fail to remove and dispose of any feces deposited by said animal upon the grounds of any public park or public place; upon any residential lot of another occupied for human habitation, or upon any right-of-way adjacent thereto, and will be done on demand by the owner or occupant thereof or the director or any animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-21, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-22. - Duty of owner to make restitution. 
It shall be the duty and unlawful for any owner or person-in-charge of any dog or any cat to fail to make reasonable restitution for damages to private or public property caused by said animal. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-22, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-23. - Companion dog accompanying disabled person (blind, deaf, etc). 
It shall be unlawful for the owner, lessee, proprietor, manager, superintendent, agent or employee of any place of public accommodation, amusement or recreation, to refuse to permit a companion dog to accompany a disabled person entering such place or making use of the accommodations available when such person is being accompanied by a companion dog; provided, that such companion dog is wearing a harness; and provided further, that such disabled person shall present for inspection credentials issued by an accredited school for training companion animals. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-23, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-24. - Transporting animals into city for purpose of impounding. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or bring, or attempt to drive or bring, any animal into the City for the purpose of having the same impounded. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-24, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-25. - Kennels and catteries. 
It shall be unlawful for any person owning more than the number of specified cats or dogs to fail to purchase a kennel or cattery license as outlined under provisions of ordinance number 472. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-25, 10-18-99)  
Secs. 4-26—4-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - LICENSE REQUIRED 
 
Sec. 4-31. - License required for dogs and cats over three (3) months of age. 
The owner or person-in-charge of every dog and cat in the city more than three (3) months of age shall annually register the same as to sex, breed, description, name and address of the owner or person-in-charge, and name of the dog or cat if any. At the time of such registration, such owner or person-in-charge shall, upon providing proof of a valid rabies vaccination, obtain a license for such a dog or cat and shall pay a license tax or fee as follows: 
SPAYED OR NEUTERED 	$2.50 CATS 	$5.00 DOGS 
UNSPAYED OR UNNEUTERED 	$5.00 CATS 	$10.00 DOGS 
 
Provided, however, that when a license is issued for a dog or cat too young to be subjected to alteration because it is less that six (6) months old at the time said license is issued, and said dog or cat is altered subsequent to the beginning of the next license year, upon proof of said alteration the director may issue said license at no charge for the following license-year period only. 
Upon the written recommendation of a licensed veterinarian, a waiver may be granted to the spay or neuter requirement when it is determined that age or health reasons may be reason for exemption. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-31, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-32. - Issuance of license. 
At the time of such registration, such owner or person-in-charge shall obtain a license for such dog or cat issued by the Director or his agent and shall be issued a metal tag or decal suitable for affixing to the license tag as evidence of such license, effective for one (1) year from the date of issue. The license must be renewed each year on or before the anniversary date of issue. Each person renewing a license more that thirty (30) days after the anniversary date shall be charged a $5.00 late fee. No valid license tag of valid decal shall be issued for any dog or cat until such dog or cat has been inoculated against rabies in accordance with state law. The provisions of this section shall not apply to dogs or cats whose owners are nonresidents, temporarily within the City for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days. 
The owner or person-in-charge shall, at all times, keep the tag affixed to said dog or cat. It shall be unlawful for any owner or person-in-charge to fail to comply fully with all requirements of this section by failing to obtain a license or otherwise. It shall also be unlawful for any person, except the owner or person-in-charge, or his agent, except for purposes of grooming or bathing, to remove a tag from a dog or cat tagged under the provisions of this section. It shall be unlawful for any person to place an unissued tag upon any dog or cat, to procure a tag from the city or its agent by fraud or misrepresentation, or to disfigure or alter the words or figures upon a tag. 
The mayor, upon recommendation of the director and of the city clerk-treasurer, may authorize any licensed veterinarian to accept applications for issuance of, on behalf of the city, the license herein required. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-32, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-33. - Harboring dogs or cats. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to harbor, keep custody or take care of more than four (4) dogs or four (4) cats, six (6) months or older who are frequently outside the residence and on the premises. Provided, however, that any owner of more than four (4) cats or four (4) dogs licensed by the city at the time of the effective date of this ordinance, which cats or dogs are frequently outside the residence and on the premises, shall be allowed to keep such cats or dogs, so long as properly licensed by the city, until the cats or dogs are no longer living, or until ownership of such cats or dogs is transferred to a person residing at another premises who is in compliance with this article. The city shall not license additional cats or dogs for such owner until the number of licensed cats or dogs which are frequently outside the residence and on the premises is less than four (4). Licensed kennels and catteries shall be exempt from these requirements. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-33, 10-18-99)  
ARTICLE IV. - CONFINEMENT AND ADOPTION 
 
Sec. 4-34. - Confinement of dogs or cats running at large; confinement of dogs or cats turned in by owner or person-in-charge; disposition of dogs or cats confined. 
(a)  Any licensed or tagged dog or cat found running at large within the city is hereby declared to be a nuisance and shall be seized by the director or an animal control officer and confined at an animal control center and cared for in a humane manner for a period of not less than three (3) days; provided, however, that the director may dispose of any dog or cat so confined, failing to have a name plate, license or current rabies tag affixed thereto in accordance with section 4-31 after only three (3) days confinement. 
(b)  Immediately upon confinement of a licensed or tagged dog or cat the director shall make reasonable effort to ascertain the identity of and notify the owner or person-in-charge of such dog or cat of its confinement and of the conditions under which possession of such animal may be regained. 
(c)  If not claimed by the owner or person-in-charge within the required period, the city may transfer ownership of any dog or cat held at a City Animal Control Center after the expiration of the legal detention period, to any animal agency approved by resolution of city council. An approved animal agency, upon obtaining possession of each such dog or cat, shall agree not to release said animal to any person other than the owner or person-in-charge until the following requirements have been met: 
(1)  Dogs and cats three (3) months of age or older have received a rabies inoculation; 
(2)  Male dogs and male cats one (1) year of age or older have been neutered; 
(3)  Female dogs and female cats six (6) months of age or older have been spayed; 
(4)  Male dogs and male cats less than one (1) year of age and female dogs and female cats less than six (6) months of age shall be adopted with the provision in the certificate of adoption requiring neutering or spaying at the proper age with the provision being accepted and signed by the adopter. 
(d)  The city shall not transfer ownership under paragraph (c) of any dog or cat known to have bitten a person or animal without justifiable provocation. 
(e)  The city shall not transfer ownership under paragraph (c) of any dog or cat that is maimed or diseased and, in the opinion of the director, not suitable for adoption. 
(f)  If the owner of an injured animal is unknown and the animal has been hospitalized by a licensed veterinarian for a period of three (3) days, said animal may be released to a veterinarian upon his/her request. 
(g)  Any dog or cat turned in by the owner or person-in-charge shall be available for immediate adoption in accordance with section 4-35, or for transfer in accordance with this section. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-34, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-35. - Redemption and adoption of dogs and cats. 
(a)  The owner or person-in-charge, entitled to possession of any dog or cat confined under the provisions of this chapter, may recover possession of such dog or cat upon payment of the charges set forth in the following section to an animal control center. 
If the owner or person-in-charge entitled to possession of any dog or cat so confined is unable to produce a certificate or satisfactory evidence of inoculation for rabies and of proper licensing of said dog or cat before the director shall release the dog or cat, fees must be paid for the inoculation and city license. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to secure any dog or cat from the animal control center without authority to do so. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any employee of an animal control center to redeem any dog or cat or become directly or indirectly interested in the redemption of any dog or cat not owned by such employee of an animal control center prior to its impoundment. 
(d)  Prior to the adoption of an animal from an Animal Control Center, the adoption application must be completed. Based on the information provided on the application, the Director or his representative has the right to deny the request to adopt an animal if he feels that the person is unable to provide a suitable home to care for the animal properly and prevent it from being a nuisance. 
(e)  Upon approval to adopt an animal from an Animal Control Center, the adoption agreement must be signed. Failure to agree to the terms shall be grounds for disqualification. 
(f)  Upon the adoption of any animal from an animal control center, the adopter shall deposit the amount of money required for a rabies vaccination, a city license, and a deposit for sterilization (spaying or neutering), if applicable as established by the director. 
(g)  Animals must be sterilized in accordance with the adoption agreement. Failure to do so will void the adoption agreement and the animal will be apprehended. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-35, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-36. - Charges for confinement for dogs and cats. 
(a)  The city shall charge and collect fees from owners who redeem their animals. The Mayor and City Council shall establish a fee schedule for an animal control center for the following categories: 
(1)  Impounding: dog or cat 
(2)  Boarding: dog and cat per day 
(3)  Adoption: dog or cat 
(4)  Special Fees: pickup, replacement tags, dead animal pickup, disposal, etc. 
(b)  The fee schedule may be reviewed and any recommended changes shall be made by Mayor and City Council. 
(c)  Animals may not be adopted by original owners or their immediate family members so as to avoid paying a violation fine or redemption fee. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-36, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-37. - When disposal of dogs or cats may take place. 
(a)  After a dog or cat has been confined for the period of time provided by section 4-34 of this article, and if the owner or person-in-charge entitled to possession fails to make application for the release of such dog or cat, as herein provided, or fails to pay the charges as herein provided, or fails to pay for the proper inoculation for rabies, or if such satisfactory evidence as required by section 4-35 was not provided, or if ownership is not transferred by the city in accordance with section 4-34, as provided herein, then such dog or cat is hereby declared a nuisance and a danger to the health, safety and welfare of the city and the manager or authorized animal control officer shall cause such dog or cat humanely to be destroyed as herein provided; however, any puppy or kitten under two (2) weeks old or whose eyes have not opened may be humanely disposed of immediately upon being impounded when found to be in violation of this chapter. 
(b)  Any confined dog or cat that is injured or diseased will, as an act of mercy, be humanely destroyed immediately after inspection by a veterinarian. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-37, 10-18-99)  
Secs. 4-38—4-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - RABIES CONTROL 
 
Sec. 4-41. - Rabies vaccination required generally. 
Every owner or person-in-charge of a dog or cat required to be immunized for rabies as defined in this act, shall cause said dog or cat to be immunized by the rabies officer, his authorized representative, or any duly licensed veterinarian, when said animal reaches three months of age and annually thereafter. Evidence of such immunization shall consist of a printed certificate furnished in triplicate by the Alabama Department of Public Health, upon which shall be legibly inscribed: a description of the dog or cat; its age, color, sex, breed, and tattoo identification, if any; the name and address of the owner; the lot number and type of vaccine used (modified live virus, inactivated virus); the name of the manufacturer and amount of vaccine injected; and a serially numbered tag bearing the same number and year as that of the certificate. 
The certificate shall be dated and signed by the person authorized to administer the vaccine. Certificates not in compliance with the provisions of this section, or certificates issued by those persons unauthorized to administer rabies vaccine, shall not be valid. The original copy of the certificate prescribed herein shall be delivered to the owner of the dog or cat immunized, one copy to the local health department, and one copy is to be retained by the rabies officer. The certificate of immunization shall be valid for a period of one year for all dogs and cats required to be immunized under this article. Immunization certificates may be destroyed three years after date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-41, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-42. - Tag to be issued at time of inoculation. 
The serially numbered tag bearing the same number and year as that of the certificate and issued coincident with the certificate of immunization shall at all times be attached to a collar or harness worn by the dog or cat for which the certificate and tag have been issued. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-42, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-43. - Lost tag; duplicate certificate. 
In the event a tag is lost when the same has been legally issued, every replacement thereof shall be upon such terms as may be agreed upon with the rabies officer or veterinarian by whom the animal has been immunized. In such instance, a new certificate marked "duplicate" may be issued setting forth the number of the new tag and the tag and the certificate issued and distributed according to section 4-41 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-43, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-44. - Attaching rabies tag to collar/harness of dogs and cats. 
The owner or person-in-charge of any dog or cat found not wearing the evidence of current immunization as provided herein or for which no certificate of current immunization can be produced, and which is apprehended by an animal control officer or other person charged with the enforcement of this act, shall forthwith be subject to a penalty to be imposed by this chapter under section 4-5. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-44, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-45. - Period of vaccination. 
The vaccination of dogs and cats against rabies shall be valid for a period of one year. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-45, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-46. - Authority of health officer. 
The health officer or his authorized agent shall have the authority to quarantine or require confinement of any or all animals for such period of time and in such manner as he may determine whenever he considers such quarantine or confinement necessary for the control of rabies. The health officer or his authorized agent shall have the right at any time to move or cause to be moved to the Animal Control Center or place designated by him for observation or examination, any animal which is reasonably suspected to be afflicted with rabies, or which has bitten or otherwise injured a human being in such manner as would permit or favor the transmission of the virus of rabies, in the event such animal should be afflicted with rabies, or which has been, or is reasonably suspected of being afflicted with rabies, and it shall be unlawful for any person to hinder, obstruct or interfere with the health officer or his authorized agent or deputy in the exercise of the authority herein conferred upon him. It shall be the duty of the health officer to destroy, or cause to be destroyed, any animal found to be afflicted with rabies. It shall be the responsible of the owner or person-in-charge, when confined for observation or examination, to pay reasonable charges for impoundment and boarding. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-46, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-47. - Quarantine of animals bitten by suspected animals. 
Those domesticated species, for which antirabies vaccine is recognized and recommended, upon exposure or potential exposure to a known rabid animal, shall be humanely destroyed or slaughtered immediately. Provided, however, the owner may have the option of quarantining said animals based on the recommendations of the Alabama Department of Public Health upon consultation with the U.S. Public Health Service, and further provided said owner shall agree to pay all charges for boarding of said animal. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-47, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-48. - Quarantine following biting of human beings; canine corps/seeing eye dog exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner or person-in-charge of any dog or cat required to be immunized against rabies and by which a human being has been bitten or exposed to notify the health officer or his authorized agent. The health officer or his authorized agent shall cause said dog or cat to be placed in quarantine under the direct supervision of a duly licensed veterinarian, chosen by owner or person-in-charge, for rabies observation for a period of ten (10) days subsequent to the date of the exposure or as otherwise directed by the health officer. The owner or person-in-charge shall be responsible for any boarding charges for said animal. It shall be unlawful for any person having knowledge that a human being has been bitten or exposed by a dog or cat to fail to notify the rabies officer or the health officer or his authorized agent. 
(b)  When said dog or cat is unowned, as determined by the rabies officer or the health officer after reasonable investigation, or where the owner of a dog or cat agrees in writing, or when ordered by the health officer, the animal shall be humanely destroyed immediately after exposure, and the head shall be submitted for rabies examination to the state health department laboratory. 
(c)  The period of quarantine for animals other than domesticated dogs and cats which have bitten or exposed a human being shall be determined by the Alabama Department of Public Health upon consultation with the U.S. Public Health Services. Provided, however, for those animal where reliable epidemiologic data are lacking regarding duration of rabies virus secretion from the salivary glands, said animals shall be humanely destroyed and the head submitted for rabies examination to the state health department laboratory. 
(d)  It shall be a violation of this article for the owner or person-in-charge of such animal to refuse to comply with the lawful order or the health officer in any particular case. It is unlawful for the owner or person-in-charge to sell, give away, transfer to another location or otherwise dispose of any such animal that is known to have bitten or exposed a human being until it is released from quarantine by the rabies officer, duly licensed veterinarian or by the appropriate health officer. 
(e)  Instructions for the quarantine of the offending animal shall be delivered in person or by telephone to the owner or person-in-charge by the health officer or his authorized agent. If such instructions cannot be delivered in such manner, they shall be mailed by regular mail, postage prepaid and addressed to the owner or person-in-charge of the animal. The affidavit or testimony of the health officer or his authorized agent, who delivers or mails such instructions, shall be prima facie evidence of the receipt of such instructions by the owner or person-in-charge of the animal. Any expenses incurred in the quarantine of the offending animal under this and the preceding section shall be borne by the owner of person-in-charge. 
(f)  The veterinarian under whose care the offending animal has been committed for quarantine shall promptly report the results of his observation of said animal to the attending physician of the human being bitten or exposed and to the appropriate health officer. 
(g)  Canine Corps dogs and Seeing Eye dogs shall be exempt from the quarantine period where such exposure occurs in the line of duty and evidence of proper immunization against rabies is presented, but shall be examined immediately at the end of 10 days by a licensed veterinarian, who shall report the result of his examination to the appropriate health officer as previously authorized. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-48, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-49. - Violations of this article. 
Any person violating or aiding or abetting the violation of any provision of this article, or counterfeiting of any certificate or tag, or making any misrepresentation in regard to any matter prescribed by this article or rule promulgated hereunder or except as otherwise provided, or resisting, obstructing or impeding any authorized officer in enforcing the provisions of this article, or refusing to produce for immunization any animal in his possession for which antirabies vaccine is recognized and recommended, or for failing to report an animal bite, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and for the purpose of enforcing this article, shall be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-49, 10-18-99)  
Secs. 4-50—4-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - DEAD ANIMALS 
 
Sec. 4-61. - Disposal of dead animals unlawful except as provided. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of any dead animal except as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-61, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-62. - Disposal generally. 
(a)  The owner of person-in-charge of animals that die or are killed in their possession or custody within twenty-four (24) hours, shall notify the appropriate city official, as set forth in section 4-63 of this article, of such dead animal and request its removal as provided in section 4-64 of this article, or shall cause the remains of such animals to be buried at least two (2) feet below the surface of the ground in accordance with this article. Animals dying from any communicable disease whatsoever shall be reported to the city in accordance with section 4-63. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-62, 10-18-99)  
Sec. 4-63. - Appropriate city official notification. 
(a)  A small dead animal such as a dog or cat shall be reported to the director or an animal control officer. 
(b)  Animals dying from any communicable disease shall be reported to the health department in addition to being reported to the appropriate official for removal. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-65, 10-18-00)  
Sec. 4-64. - Removal by the city. 
When a request is made to the director or an animal control officer for removal of a small dead animal, it shall thereupon be the duty of the official receiving the request to demand of such person his name and address, including street and house number, and a description of the dead animal. Immediately upon receipt of the information demanded, the official receiving the request shall cause the remains of such dead animal to be removed and buried at least two (2) feet below the surface of the ground or to be burned. If the death is due to a communicable disease, the remains shall be burned. However, the director or an animal control officer may require that the requesting party place said small dead animal in a securely fastened plastic bag or similar container and make the same accessible at the curb or at such other place upon the property as he may direct. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-64, 10-18-00)  
Secs. 4-65—4-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - EDUCATIONAL 
 
Sec. 4-71. - Authority to promote. 
(a)  The Mayor of the City of Guntersville or his duly authorized representative is hereby authorized to promote the provisions of this ordinance through educational efforts and programs designed to acquaint the general public as to the requirements, stimulations and penalties of this ordinance. 
(b)  The Mayor is hereby authorized to advertise any provisions of this ordinance. 
(c)  The Mayor is hereby authorized to designate certain periods of time wherein owners or persons-in-charge of dogs and cats may qualify for spaying and neutering services for such animals from local veterinarians at discounted rates. The Mayor is further authorized to advertise such events. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-71, 10-18-00)  
Sec. 4-72. - Violations and penalties. 
That the violation, other than provided for under section 4-5 (animal fine schedule) and section 4-50 (rabies), of the provisions, of this chapter and regulations promulgated under the authority of this ordinance by the City of Guntersville, Alabama, is hereby declared to be a misdemeanor and any person, firm, or corporation found guilty of such misdemeanor shall be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00), nor more than One hundred dollars ($100.00) or by imprisonment of not more than thirty (30) days, or both, for each violation. Each day a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 816, § 5-72, 10-18-00)  
Secs. 4-73—4-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - LIVESTOCK STABLES AND ENCLOSURES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 816, adopted Oct. 18, 1999 amended ch. 4 in its entirety, in order keep the alpha-numeric sequence, §§ 40—48 are herein renumbered as §§ 81—89, at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 4-81. - Livestock at large prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person who owns or has under his control any horse, cow, mule, hog, goat, sheep, or other animal of like kind, or any chicken, turkey or similar domestic fowl, to permit the same to be at large in the streets or upon the premises not his own or under his care or control within the city or within the police jurisdiction thereof. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 9-6-94)  
Sec. 4-82. - Exemptions. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to licensed stockyards, holding pens, sale barns, wholesale cattle dealers or slaughter houses. This article shall no application to small domestic type pets usually maintained in the owner's home such as pet birds, noncommercial rabbits, chickens and other type fowl. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 2, 9-6-94)  
Sec. 4-83. - Stable required. 
Every person, firm, association or corporation who shall maintain a horse, mule, cow, hog, goat, sheep, or any other animal of like kind, or any chicken, turkey, or similar domestic fowl within the corporate limits of the city shall provide a stable, shed, or pen for such animal or animals. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 3, 9-6-94)  
Sec. 4-84. - Distance and space requirements. 
(a)  Distance requirements for swine. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, individually or collectively to keep within the city limits of the city any animals of the swine type unless such are kept at all times a distance of five thousand (5,000) feet or more from any residence other than the keeper of such animals, church, school, public building, park, playground or cafe. 
(b)  Distance requirements for horses, mules, cows, sheep, rabbits, monkeys, fowl. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, individually or collectively, to keep within the city limits, any animals of the equine type and animals of the bovine type, any animals of the ovine type and rabbits or animals of the hare family, any monkeys, and fowl, to include chickens, turkeys, ducks, geese, guineas, quail, pheasants, or other fowl unless such animals are kept at all times at a distance of five thousand (5,000) feet or more from any residence other than the residence of the keeper of such animals or town, church, school, public building, park, playground or cafe. 
(c)  Space requirements for pastures in residential, commercial and industrial district. It shall be unlawful to keep any of such livestock described above in a residential, commercial, or industrial district as defined by the zoning ordinance of the city unless such pasture shall have a minimum area of twenty thousand (20,000) square feet for one (1) such animal and four thousand (4,000) square feet for each additional animal there kept, to every portion of which such animal shall have free and unrestricted access. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 4, 9-6-94)  
Sec. 4-85. - Sanitation. 
Every stable, shed, pen, or lot where any livestock is kept in the city shall be kept clean and dry and shall have sufficient light to make cleaning practicable, and shall have sufficient ventilation to keep the air of such building pure at all times. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 5, 9-6-94)  
Sec. 4-86. - Food bin; control of feed. 
All such stables, sheds or pens shall have a food bin for the storage of food which shall be of rat-proof construction; all grain, malt, or other animal food, except hay stored or kept in such stable, must be kept in a feed bin. Such feed bin must be kept closed at all times except when momentarily opened to take food therefrom, or when the same is being filled. No feed shall be scattered about outside such bin or in the stable, and all such feed found on the floor or in the stall of such stable shall be removed daily and placed in the manure receptacle. No feed stuff intended for human consumption shall be kept or stored in any stable or any place where animals are kept. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 6, 9-6-94)  
Sec. 4-87. - Manure and litter containers. 
Every such stable, shed, or pen shall have either within or immediately adjoining it an approved fly-proof container or room for receiving and holding animal manure and litter accumulating between times of removal from the premises. The fitness of such container shall be passed upon by an agent of the sanitary department of the city. The bin or container shall be located at a point most remote from any dwelling or other structure owned or occupied by other than the owner of such premises and shall likewise be placed at a place most remote on the premises from any street or avenue. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 7, 9-6-94)  
Sec. 4-88. - Storage and disposition of manure and other waste. 
All accumulations of manure and bedding materials soiled by animal waste in and about such stable, shed, pen or pasture shall be collected at least once each day and immediately deposited in the container above provided. Such collection may be kept stored within the container for a period of not more than two (2) days, after which time the collection may be kept stored within the container for a period of not more than two (2) days, after which time the collection shall be removed from the premises and disposed of in such a manner as to prevent fly breeding therein. In lieu of storage as herein provided, manure and the other soiled material, when collected in accordance with the provisions hereof and being free of live fly larvae or pupae, may be disposed of within twenty-four (24) hours from time of collection, by surface of the ground at some place distant from human habitation so that the collection will be fully exposed to the effects of sunlight, provided, however, that any of such persons may used the manure on the premises for the purpose of enriching their own ground or for any other use to which manure can properly be put when the same is not offensive or unsanitary and further providing that same does not emit any obnoxious odors or smells. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 8, 9-6-94)  
Sec. 4-89. - Penalty. 
Any violation of this article by any person, firm, association or corporation shall be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment in jail or at hard labor for a period for not exceeding six (6) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 9, 9-6-94)  
Secs. 4-90—4-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - DOG PARKS 
 
Sec. 4-101. - Definitions. 
Attendant means a person fourteen (14) years or older who brings a dog to the dog park. Such person is expected to be competent and knowledgeable relative to the behavior of, and have control over, said dog(s) at all times while at or inside the facility. 
Dog park means an enclosed fence facility designated by the City of Guntersville for the purpose of allowing dogs, under the control of their owner or attendant, to exercise and socialize off-leash. 
Owner means any person, partnership or corporation owning, keeping or harboring one (1) or more dogs. A dog shall be deemed to be harbored if it is fed or sheltered for seven (7) consecutive days or more. 
Vicious dog means a dog that: 
(1)  Without justification, attacks a person or domestic animal causing physical injury or death; 
(2)  Has a known history of attacks on people or other domestic animals; or 
(3)  Behaves in a manner that a reasonable person would believe imposes an unjustified imminent threat of physical injury or death to a person or to a domestic or owned animal. 
Visual control means the attendant can see the dog(s) and is within one hundred (100) feet of the dog(s) at all times. 
Voice control means the attendant is within one hundred (100) feet of the dog(s), is able to control and recall the dog(s) at all times and is not allowing the dog(s) to fight with other dogs. A dog under voice control must immediately come to the attendant when so commanded. 
(Ord. No. 1060, § 1, 2-2-15)  
Sec. 4-102. - Park operations. 
The director of parks and recreation shall have authority to control and maintain the dog park consistent with this article. The dog park will be operated on a daily basis from sunrise to sunset, unless closed for maintenance or severe weather. 
The dog park shall be divided into two (2) areas: 
(1)  For dogs under twenty-five (25) pounds; 
(2)  For dogs twenty-five (25) pounds and over. 
(Ord. No. 1060, § 1, 2-2-15)  
Sec. 4-103. - Responsibilities of dog park users. 
All dogs must be under the direct supervision of an attendant. 
The attendant must ensure that their dog(s) are legally licensed and have documentation that their dog's vaccinations are up to date. Current license, vaccination tags and identification of owner must be displayed on the dog's collar. 
All dogs shall be free of contagious or infectious diseases, be parasite free both externally and internally and have no visible wounds or injuries. 
No more than two (2) dogs per attendant are allowed in the dog park. 
The attendant of the dog(s) must be inside the enclosed dog park and have visual and voice control of their dog(s) at all times. Dogs shall not be left unattended at or inside the facility. 
All dogs must be wearing a collar. Spike, choke and electronic collars are not permitted. 
The attendant of any dog(s) using the facility must have in his hand a leash at all times which must be attached to the dog(s) when outside the facility area. 
The attendant must fill in any holes dug at the facility by their dog(s). 
The attendant must remove their dog(s) when they become engaged in excessive barking or are fighting with other dogs. 
The attendant of dogs using the facility must use a suitable container to promptly remove any feces deposited by their dog(s) and properly dispose of such waste material in designated receptacles. 
The attendant must wear shoes at all times while inside the fenced area of the dog park. 
The dog park gates must be closed securely when entering and exiting the dog park. 
(Ord. No. 1060, § 1, 2-2-15)  
Sec. 4-104. - Children regulations. 
While inside the facility, children under fourteen (14) years of age shall be accompanied by an adult of nineteen (19) years of age or older who is solely responsible for each child's proper behavior and safety. Such children are not permitted to excite or antagonize any dogs using the facility by any means including, but not limited to, shouting, screaming, waving their arms, throwing objects, running at or chasing dogs. 
(Ord. No. 1060, § 1, 2-2-15)  
Sec. 4-105. - Prohibited actions. 
To ensure the safety of the dogs and attendants, the following are not permitted at the dog park: 
(1)  Animals that are not dogs; 
(2)  Dogs under the age of three (3) months; 
(3)  Dogs who have not been spayed or neutered; 
(4)  Female dogs in heat within three hundred (300) feet of the dog park; 
(5)  Dogs deemed to be vicious, or who have a previous history of aggressive behavior toward other animals or humans; 
(6)  The use of bicycles, roller blades/skates, skateboards and similar types of exercise equipment; 
(7)  Motorized vehicles and devices, except for wheelchairs for the disabled; 
(8)  Glass bottles and similar breakable containers; 
(9)  Alcoholic beverages; 
(10)  Smoking; 
(11)  Food of any type, including dog biscuits/treats; and 
(12)  Professional dog trainers may not use the facility in conjunction with the operation of their business. 
(Ord. No. 1060, § 1, 2-2-15)  
Sec. 4-106. - Liability. 
Users of the dog park shall comply with all rules and regulations governing the use of the facility. 
The owner and/or attendant is responsible for and liable for all injuries and damages caused by their dog(s). 
Use of the dog park shall constitute the implied consent of the dog owner and/or attendant to all conditions of this article and shall constitute a waiver of liability to the City of Guntersville. As such, users of the dog park agree and undertake to protect, indemnify, defend and hold the City of Guntersville harmless for any injury or damage caused by or to their dog(s) during any time that said dog(s) is at the dog park. 
(Ord. No. 1060, § 1, 2-2-15)  
Sec. 4-107. - Enforcement. 
A person found to be in violation of this article is subject to removal from the facility and may be prohibited from future use of the dog park. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be subject to a one hundred dollar ($100.00) fine for the first offense and two hundred dollar ($200.00) fine for any subsequent offense. 
(Ord. No. 1060, § 1, 2-2-15)  
Chapter 5 - BUILDINGS; CONSTRUCTION AND RELATED ACTIVITIES[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Vehicle loads, transporting on streets, 16-51 et seq.; no permit to be issued until building number assigned, § 16-2(b); permit to excavate on streets, § 16-4; site plan review, App. A, § 8-1; building permit requirements, App. A, § 13-2 et seq.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 5-1. - Building official—Office established; function. 
There is hereby established in the city the office of building official, which official is charged with the enforcement of the codes adopted herein. The terms "building official," "administrative officer" and "building inspector" as used in this Code are interchangeable. 
(Ord. No. 372, § 102.1, 8-28-62)  
Sec. 5-2. - Requirements not covered by codes. 
Any requirement not specifically covered by the codes herein adopted, found necessary for the safety, health, and general welfare of the occupants of any building shall be determined by the building official subject to appeal to the board of adjustment. 
(Ord. No. 372, § 103.3, 8-28-62)  
Sec. 5-3. - Liability. 
Any officer or employee or member of the board of adjustment charged with the enforcement of the codes, acting for the city in the discharge of official duties, shall not thereby render such person's self liable personally, and such person is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of official duties. Any suit brought against any officer or employee or member because of enforcement of such codes shall be defended by the city attorney until the final termination of the proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 372, § 103.5, 8-28-62)  
Sec. 5-4. - Same—Records. 
The building official shall keep, or cause to be kept, a record of the business of the office. The records shall be open to public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 372, § 102.5, 8-28-62)  
Sec. 5-5. - Same—Reports. 
The building official shall annually submit a report to the council covering the work of the office during the preceding year. The building official shall incorporate in the report a summary of the decisions of the board of adjustment during such year. 
(Ord. No. 372, § 103.6, 8-28-62)  
Sec. 5-6. - Same—Conflict of interest. 
No officer or employee connected with the building official's office except one whose only connection is as a member of the board of adjustment, shall be financially interested in the furnishing of labor, material, or appliances for the construction, alteration, or maintenance of a building, or in the making of plans or of specifications therefor, unless such person is the owner of such building. No such officer or employee shall engage in any work which is inconsistent with such person's duties or with the interests of the office. 
(Ord. No. 372, § 102.2, 8-28-62)  
Sec. 5-7. - Board of appeals for unsafe building abatement. 
There is hereby designated a building code board of appeals. The mayor is authorized and empowered to appoint five (5) residents of the city to serve on said board. The members shall be qualified by experience and training to pass on matters pertaining to building construction, property maintenance and related matters. No member shall be an employee of the city. The code official shall be an ex-officio member, but shall have no vote on any matter before the board. The board shall serve staggered and overlapping terms. 
(Ord. No. 587, § 2, 1-20-86; Ord. No. 694, § 2, 1-25-93; Ord. No. 844, § 2, 3-18-02; Ord. No. 935, § 2, 3-19-07)  
Sec. 5-8. - Technical codes adopted.

The following sections are hereby revised:

Section 1612.3. Insert: The City of Guntersville, Alabama 
Section 1612.3. Insert: August 19, 1991

Section 106 Violation Penalties is hereby repealed and replaced with the following new section: 
106.4 Violation Penalties. For any and every violation of the provisions of this ordinance, and for each and every day that such violations continues, said violation(s) shall be punishable as a misdemeanor by a fine not to exceed $100.00 per day, or by imprisonment for not more than ten days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
Persons charged with such violation(s) may include: 
The owner, agent, lessee, tenant, contractor or any other person using the land, building or premises where such violation has been committed or shall exist. 
Any person, who knowingly commits, takes part or assists in such violation. 
Any person who maintains any land, building or premises in which such violation(s) shall exist. 
Section 302 Exterior Property Areas 
Section 302.1 Sanitation is hereby repealed and replaced with the following new section: 
302.1 Sanitation. All exterior property and premises shall be maintained in a clean, safe and sanitary condition. The exterior area shall include unenclosed porches, carports, patios, accessory storage buildings, and any other area open to view. Clean, safe and sanitary conditions includes exterior property without visible garbage, refuse, junk, debris, salvage materials of any nature, household furniture, trash, unused motor vehicle tires, kitchen and other household appliances and rubbish.

Section 304.14. Insert: January 1 to December 31 
Section 307 - Rubbish and garbage. 
Subsection 307.2.2 Refrigerators is hereby repealed and replaced with the following new subsection: 
307.2.2 Refrigerators and appliances. Refrigerators and household appliances (water heaters, dishwashers, plumbing fixtures, and etc.) not in operation shall not be discarded, abandoned or stored on the exterior premises. Before disposal of refrigerators all doors shall be removed. 
Section 308 - Extermination. 
Add subsection 308.6 as follows: 
308.6 Mosquito control. The occupants of any structure shall be responsible to maintain the exterior area of all property and premises to eliminate mosquito-breeding habitat. Any container that could hold water shall be removed from the premises or stored in a manner so that water shall not collect in the container conducive to mosquito breeding.
