Cross reference— Damaging or obstructing drainage ditches, § 16-5; discharge of water onto sidewalks, § 16-6. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 12-1. - Grant of electricity franchise to board. 
(a)  The words "the city" as used herein shall mean the City of Guntersville in the State of Alabama as it may at any time be constituted. The words "the board" as used herein mean Electric Board of Guntersville, a public corporation organized under the provisions of Act No. 175 adopted at the 1951 Regular Session of the Legislature of Alabama. 
(b)  There is hereby granted to the board the right, privilege, power and franchise to acquire, construct, own, maintain and operate in the city a system for the distribution of electricity for heat, light and power to the city and to its inhabitants and any person, firm or corporation within or outside of the city for public or private uses, and the consent of the city is hereby granted to the board to use the streets, avenues, alleys and other public ways and public places in the city for the aforesaid purposes. There is hereby further granted to the board the right, privilege and power at any time and from time to time, without any requirement as to permit or fee therefor, to repair, renew, extend, enlarge, add to and improve the said system and to construct in, over, along and under any street, avenue, alley or other public way or public place in the city all poles, towers, guy wires, cross arms, wires and cables and other parts used or useful as a part of or in connection with the system, and to make all necessary excavations therefor. 
(c)  The board shall, and by accepting this franchise agrees, that it will upon making any excavations of the streets, avenues, alleys, public ways and public places in the city, restore the surface or paving at the point of such excavation in substantially the same condition as before such work was done, all as may be practicable and within a reasonable time thereafter. 
(d)  The rights, privileges, power and franchise herein granted may be exercised by the board or any successors and assigns of the board, all subject nevertheless to the conditions and obligations herein contained. 
(e)  The rights, privileges, power and franchise herein granted shall remain in full force and effect for a period of thirty (30) years from the effective date of this ordinance. 
(f)  This article shall be published as required by law in a newspaper publication and having general circulation in the city and shall become effective in accordance with law. 
(Ord. No. 663, §§ 1—6, 1-7-91) 
Cross reference— Excavation permit, § 16-4.  
Sec. 12-2. - Grant of gas franchise to district (Reserved).  
Sec. 12-3. - Grant of water works and sewer franchise to board. 
(a)  The word "city" as used herein means the City of Guntersville, Alabama, as it is now constituted and as it may hereafter be extended or enlarged. The words "the board" as used herein mean the water works and sewer board of the city, a public corporation under the laws of the state. 
(b)  There is hereby granted to the board the right, privilege, authority and franchise to acquire, own, operate, construct, enlarge and improve in the city a water works plant and distribution system, and a sanitary sewer system, or either of them, for the purpose of supplying water and sanitary sewer service in the city and the surrounding territory and to the inhabitants thereof, and to use the streets, avenues, alleys and public ways and places in the city for such purposes. 
(c)  The city hereby grants to the board the right, privilege, authority and franchise at any time and from time to time during the period covered by this franchise and without any requirement as to permit or fee therefor, to lay construction and maintain pipes and mains and other conductors, fixtures and related appurtenances in, along, across and under the streets, avenues, alleys and other public places in the city, and to repair, renew, relay and extend such pipes and mains, conductors, fixtures and related appurtenances and to make all excavations necessary therefor. 
(d)  The board shall, and by accepting this franchise agrees that it will, upon making any excavation in the streets, avenues, alleys, public ways and public places of the city, restore the surface or paving at the point of such excavation in substantially the same condition as before such work was done, all as promptly as may be practicable and within a reasonable length of time thereafter. 
(e)  The rights, privileges, franchises and authorities hereby granted may be exercised by the board or any successor or assign of the board and may be mortgaged and conveyed in trust by the board as security for any bonds or other obligations hereafter issued by it, all subject, nevertheless, to the conditions and obligations herein contained. 
(f)  The franchise granted hereby shall be effective for a period of thirty (30) years. 
(Ord. No. 524, §§ 1—6, 3-3-80) 
Cross reference— Excavation permit, § 16-4.  
Secs. 12-4—12-19. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - USE OF SEWERS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 12-20. - Abbreviations. 
The following abbreviations shall have the designated meanings: 
ADEM: The Alabama Department of Environmental Management. 
BOD: Biochemical oxygen demand. 
CFR: Code of Federal Regulations. 
EPA: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
NPDES: National pollutant discharge elimination system. 
OSHA: Occupational safety and health administration. 
P.L.: Public law. 
POTW: Publicly owned treatment works. 
SS: Suspended solids. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 1.01, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-21. - Definitions. 
The following terms, wherever used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Act or the act: The Federal Water Pollution Control Act (P.L. 92-500), as amended by the Clean Water Act of 1977 (P.L. 95-217) and as further amended. 
Authorized representative of industrial user: An authorized representative of an industrial user shall be: 
(1)  A principal executive officer of at least the level of vice-president if the industrial user is a corporation. 
(2)  A duly authorized representative of the individual designated above if such representative is responsible for the overall operation of the facilities from which the indirect discharge originates. 
Biochemical oxygen demand or BOD: The quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees centigrade (sixty-eight (68) degrees Fahrenheit) expressed in terms of weight and volume (milligrams per liter). 
Board: The water works and sewer board of the city. 
Building sewer or house connection: The connecting pipe from a building to the sanitary sewer. 
Combined sewer: A sewer receiving both surface runoff and wastewater. 
Cooling water: The water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, or to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
Direct discharge: The discharge of treated or untreated wastewater directly to the waters of the state. 
Domestic wastewater: All liquid and waterborne pollutants, exclusive of "unpolluted wastewater" as defined herein or wastewater or wastes from processes or operations of "industrial users" as defined herein. 
Environmental protection agency or EPA: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency or, where appropriate, the term may also be used as a designation for the administrator or other duly authorized official of such agency. 
Holding tank waste: Any waste from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks, vacuum-pump tank trucks, and septic tank haulers. 
Indirect discharge: The discharge or the introduction of nondomestic pollutants from any source regulated under section 307(b) or (c) of the act into the sewerage system (including holding tank waste discharged into the sewerage system). 
Industrial user: Any user of the sewerage system who is a source of indirect discharge which does not constitute a "discharge of pollutants" under regulations issued pursuant to section 402 of the act. (A user who discharges industrial waste into the sewerage system.) 
Industrial waste: The liquid or other wastes resulting from any process of industry, manufacture, trade or business or from the development of natural resources. 
Manager: The administrative officer of the water works and sewer board of the city, who is charged with administrative control of all operations of the board and is responsible directly to the board. As used herein, it may also include any other board employee delegated to act for the board by the manager or by the board. 
National pollutant discharge elimination system or NPDES permit: A permit to discharge wastewater issued pursuant to section 402 of the act. 
Pollutant: Any solid waste, chemical waste, biological material, radioactive material, thermal waste, or industrial, municipal or agricultural waste discharged into water. 
Pollution: The manmade or man-induced alteration of the chemical, physical, biological, and/or radiological integrity of water. 
Private wastewater disposal system: Any facilities for wastewater treatment and disposal not maintained and operated by the city. 
Properly shredded garbage: The organic wastes resulting from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of foods that have been shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particles being greater that one-half inch in any dimension. 
Public sewer: A sewer in which all owners of abutting properties shall have equal rights, and which is controlled by a governmental agency or public utility. 
Publicly owned treatment works or POTW: Treatment works as defined by section 212 of the act which are owned in this instance by the water works and sewer board of the city. This definition includes the wastewater treatment plant and any sewers that convey wastewater to the wastewater treatment plant (sewerage system). 
Receiving stream: That body of water, stream, or watercourse receiving the discharge from a wastewater treatment plant or that body of water, stream, or watercourse formed by the effluent from a wastewater treatment plant. 
Sanitary sewage: Sewage excluding process wastes from industrial users. 
Sanitary sewer: A public sewer controlled by a governmental agency or public utility that carries liquid and waterborne wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with minor quantities of ground and surface waters that are not admitted intentionally. 
Sewage: A combination of water-carried wastes from residences and industrial users (wastewater). 
Sewer: A pipe or conduit for carrying wastewater. 
Sewerage system: All facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of wastewater (POTW). 
Significant industrial user: Any industrial user of the city sewerage system who: 
(1)  Has a discharge flow of twenty-five thousand (25,000) gallons or more per average work day. 
(2)  Has a discharge which is greater than five (5) percent of the hydraulic flow or organic design capacity of the city sewerage system. 
(3)  Has a discharge which contains toxic pollutants or priority pollutants as defined pursuant to section 307 of the act or state statutes and rules and regulations. 
(4)  Is found by the water works and sewer board, the approval authority or EPA to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on the sewerage system, the quality of sludge, the system's effluent quality, or air emissions generated by the sewerage system. 
Storm sewer or storm drain: A sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but which excludes sanitary sewage and polluted industrial wastes. 
Storm water: Any flow occurring during or following any form of natural precipitation and resulting therefrom. 
Suspended solids: The total solid matter that either floats on the surface of or is suspended in water or liquid waste and which is removable by laboratory filtration. 
Unpolluted wastewater: Any wastewater which is substantially free of pollutants and is discharged from the following: 
(1)  Rain downspouts and drains. 
(2)  Footing drains. 
(3)  Storm and surface water drains. 
(4)  Cooling water systems. 
Unpolluted wastewater shall contain, by definition, none of the following: 
a.  BOD in excess of ten (10) mg/l. 
b.  Suspended solids in excess of ten (10) mg/l. 
c.  Free or emulsified greases or oils. 
d.  Acids or alkalies. 
e.  Phenols or other substances imparting taste or order to receiving waters. 
f.  Toxic or poisonous substances. 
g.  Noxious or odorous gases. 
h.  Any wastewater with a temperature which exceeds sixty (60) degrees centigrade (one hundred forty (140) degrees Fahrenheit) at its introduction into a storm sewer or which exceeds forty (40) degrees centigrade (one hundred four (104) degrees Fahrenheit) at its introduction into a receiving stream. 
User: Any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of wastewater into the sewerage system. 
Wastewater: Sewage. 
Wastewater treatment plant: The facilities of the city for treating and disposing of wastewater. 
Watercourse: A channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
Water works and sewer board or board: The water works and sewer board of the city, or, where appropriate, the term may also be used as a designation for the manager or other duly authorized official of the board. 
Waters of the state: All bodies or accumulations of water, surface or underground, within the boundaries of the state. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 1.02, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-22. - Protection of equipment. 
No person shall maliciously, wilfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, deface, tamper with, or remove any equipment or materials which are a part of the sewerage system or any equipment or materials used by the board or ADEM for the purpose of making waste examinations and waste flow measurements and left upon the premises of a user discharging wastes into the sewerage system. Only persons authorized by the board or ADEM will be allowed to uncover, adjust, maintain, and remove such equipment and materials. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 5, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-23. - Violations and penalties. 
A violation of or failure to comply with any of the provisions of this article, including the wilful furnishing of false information relative to same for the use of the sewerage system, shall be and hereby is declared to be a misdemeanor. Upon conviction, any person in violation of or failure to comply with any of the provisions of this article or the use by any person of the sewerage system in violation of this article shall be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and otherwise punished as provided in section 1-8, for each violation. Each day a violation occurs or continues shall constitute a separate violation hereunder. Every person concerned in the violation of the provisions of this article or failure to comply with same, or who furnishes false information relative to such person's use of the sewerage system aforesaid, whether such person directly commits the acts or aids and abets same, and whether present or absent, shall be proceeded against and held as a principal. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 6, 2-7-83)  
Secs. 12-24—12-29. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS 
 
Sec. 12-30. - Unsanitary deposit of waste on property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city, any human excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 2.01, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-31. - Discharge of untreated waste to outlet other than sanitary sewer. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge to any outlet other than a sanitary sewer, within the corporate limits of the city, any domestic or industrial wastes except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article and regulations of the waterworks and sewer board and where an appropriate NPDES permit has been obtained from ADEM pursuant to section 402 of the act. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 2.02, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-32. - Discharge of cooling water to storm sewer. 
Where a storm sewer is adjacent to a property, cooling water which meets the requirements of unpolluted wastewater definition, shall be discharged into the storm sewer in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article, provided that the city determines that sufficient capacity of such storm sewer and where an appropriate NPDES permit has been obtained from ADEM pursuant to section 402 of the act. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 2.03, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-33. - Connection to sanitary sewer—Required after ninety-day notice. 
The owners of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or any other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located within two hundred (200) feet of such property a public sanitary sewer of the city that discharges to the city wastewater treatment plant, are hereby required at the owners' expense to connect such facilities directly with the proper sanitary sewer in accordance with provisions of this article and regulations of the board within ninety (90) days after date of official notice to do so. These connections shall be made in accordance with provisions of division 4 of this article and regulations of the board. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 2.04, 2-7-83) 
Cross reference— Connection permit, § 12-41.  
Sec. 12-34. - Same—Performance by city after ten-day notice. 
In the event the owner of any property available to a public sanitary sewer does not cause the required connection of such property to the sewerage system to be made, the city clerk shall give written notice to such owner to connect such property to the sewer system. In the event that such owner fails or refuses to connect such property to the sewerage system within ten (10) days following such date that the notice is given, the city may make such connection, or cause such connection to be made, by condemnation if necessary, at the expense of such owner. The cost of making such connection shall constitute a lien upon such property in favor of the city, prior and superior to all liens other than liens for taxes, to be collected as other debts are collected and liens enforced. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 2.05, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-35. - Same—Constructive service of notice. 
(a)  In the event the owner of any property to whom the notice provided in section 12-34 is required to be given to a nonresident, notice shall be given to such owner by publication once a week for three (3) consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation published in the city, by mailing a copy by certified mail, return receipt requested, of such notice to such owner at such owner's last known address, and by delivering a copy of such notice to the agent or occupant of such property. 
(b)  Whenever any notice to a resident owner of property available to sewers is returned "not found," the city clerk may prescribe alias notices to be served as in the case of the original notice; two (2) returns of "not found" to such a resident owner shall authorize the city clerk to proceed to give notice to such resident owner in the manner provided in subsection (a) of this section for nonresident owners of property available to sewers. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 2.06, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-36. - Same—Collection of cost. 
In the event property available to sewers is connected to the sewerage system by the city pursuant to the provisions of section 12-34, the city council shall thereafter adopt a resolution assessing the cost or expense of making such connection against such property. Promptly after the adoption of such resolution, the city clerk shall prepare a statement in writing, setting forth the name of the owner of such property and a description of such property and stating the cost of connecting such property with the sewerage system. Such statement shall be filed with the probate judge for record in mortgage records of the county. The filing of such statement shall operate as notice of such lien from the date of its filing. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 2.07, 2-7-83)  
Secs. 12-37—12-39. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PRIVATE WASTEWATER DISPOSAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Required connections, § 12-33 et seq. 
 
Sec. 12-40. - Private system authorized. 
Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 12-33, such toilet and other facilities necessary for the discharge of domestic and/or industrial wastes shall be connected to a private wastewater disposal system complying with the requirements of the state, county and city, including the provisions of the city building code. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 3.01, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-41. - Permit. 
Before commencement of construction of a private wastewater disposal system, the owners shall first obtain a written permit from the appropriate regulatory authority and furnish a copy thereof to the city. The copy of the permit shall be accompanied by such supplementary data as deemed necessary by the city to maintain an accurate file of such private wastewater disposal systems to facilitate the planning of future public sewer service. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 3.02, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-42. - Compliance as to type, capacity, location and layout. 
The type, capacity, location, and layout of a private wastewater disposal system, including methods of sludge disposal, shall comply with all requirements of the state, county and city. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 3.03, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-43. - Connection to public sewer when available. 
At such time as a public sewer becomes available within two hundred (200) feet of a property served by a private wastewater disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer within ninety (90) days in compliance with this article and regulations of the board. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 3.04, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-44. - Operation and maintenance in sanitary manner. 
The owners shall operate and maintain any private wastewater disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 3.05, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-45. - Discharge of waste accumulation to public system. 
No person shall discharge any holding tank wastes or septic tank wastes from private systems into the sewerage system without an appropriate permit from the board. All such discharges shall be in accordance with regulations of the board. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 3.06, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-46. - Additional requirements. 
No statement contained in this division shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by federal or state agencies. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 3.07, 2-7-83)  
Secs. 12-47—12-49. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - BUILDING SEWERS, CONNECTIONS AND PERMITS 
 
Sec. 12-50. - Work permit required. 
No unauthorized persons shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the board. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 4.01, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-51. - Bearing of expenses; indemnification of city. 
(a)  All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owners. 
(b)  The owners shall indemnify the city from any loss and damage that may be directly or indirectly occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 4.02, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-52. - Separate and independent building sewer. 
A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except that, where one (1) building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building sewer for the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one (1) building sewer, but the city does not and will not assume any obligation or responsibility from damage caused by or resulting from any such single connection aforementioned. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 4.03, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-53. - Use of existing building sewer. 
Existing building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found on examination and test by the board to meet all the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 4.04, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-54. - Construction requirements generally. 
The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing, and back-filling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the city building code or other applicable rules and regulations of the board. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 4.05, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-55. - Elevation. 
Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 4.06, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-56. - Connection requirements generally. 
The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the city building code and other applicable rules and regulations of the city, or the procedures set forth in the appropriate specifications of the ASTM and the WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight and verified by proper testing. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the city before installation. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 4.07, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-57. - Notice of readiness for inspection and connection. 
The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the board when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection and testing shall be made under the supervision of the board. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 4.08, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 12-58. - Excavations. 
(a)  All excavations for building sewer installations shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazards. 
(b)  Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the board. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 4.07, 2-7-83) 
Cross reference— Excavation permit, § 16-4.  
Sec. 12-59. - OSHA compliance. 
All construction activities shall conform to all applicable OSHA regulations. 
(Ord. No. 547, § 4.10, 2-7-83)  
Secs. 12-60—12-64. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - GREASE INTERCEPTORS AT RESTAURANTS 
 
Sec. 12-65. - Definitions. 
As used in these definitions the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
Enforcement officer: The building inspector. 
Food: All articles used for food, drink, confectionery or condiment, whether simple, mixed or compound, and all substances or ingredients used in the preparation thereof. 
Grease interceptor: That device which collects grease or fatty substances before they are introduced into the sewage disposal system. 
Restaurant: Any restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, short order cafe, luncheonette, tavern, sandwich stand, drug store, and soda fountain serving food, and all other eating or drinking establishments, as well as kitchens or other places in which food or drink is prepared for sale elsewhere. 
(Ord. No. 639, § 1, 3-6-89)  
Sec. 12-66. - Enforcement. 
This division shall be enforced by the city building inspector or any police officer of the city. 
(Ord. No. 639, § 7, 3-6-89)  
Sec. 12-67. - Permits required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a restaurant in the city who does not possess an unrevoked permit for the operation of a grease interceptor from the city building inspector. Such permit shall be posted in a conspicuous place. 
(Ord. No. 639, § 2, 3-6-89)  
Sec. 12-68. - Installation of grease interceptors. 
(a)  All restaurants which exist or which are constructed, reconstructed, or extensively altered, or which shall be licensed, shall install grease interceptors in accordance with the requirements of this division before a business license is issued for the operation of a restaurant. Properly prepared plans for the installation of the grease interceptors shall be submitted to the water and sewer board before work is begun. 
(b)  All such grease interceptors shall be installed in accordance with the provisions of the city plumbing code. 
(Ord. No. 639, §§ 5, 6, 3-6-89)  
Sec. 12-69. - Inspection of restaurants. 
At least once every six (6) months, the building inspector shall inspect every restaurant located within the city. In the event such inspector discovers the violation of any item required for the proper disposal of grease or fatty substances in a proper grease interceptor, such inspector shall give to the restaurant owner or operator a reasonable amount of time for the defect to be remedied. Upon the reasonable time having expired, and the building inspector finding that the violation has not been corrected, the inspector may issue a citation to the restaurant owner or operator for violation of this division. 
(Ord. No. 639, § 3, 3-6-89)  
Sec. 12-70. - Access to premises. 
The person operating the restaurant shall upon the request of the building inspector permit access to all parts of the establishment for purposes of permitting the building inspector to make inspections. 
(Ord. No. 639, § 4, 3-6-89)  
Secs. 12-71—12-79. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1003, adopted Oct. 18, 2010, amended Ord. Nos. 546, 645, and 760, from which Art. III, §§ 12-80—12-96 derived, in their entirety to read as herein set out. 
Cross reference— Littering, unlawful accumulations, § 11-20 et seq. 
 
Sec. 12-80. - Purpose. 
The city is hereby authorized and directed to operate and manage garbage, rubbish and other solid waste collection and disposal in accordance with all applicable state and federal laws including, but not limited to, the solid waste disposal act, set out in Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-1 et seq. The city is further authorized to provide for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of cost of collection and disposal of garbage, rubbish, and other solid waste. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 1, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 1003, § 1, 10-18-10)  
Sec. 12-81. - Definitions. 
The following words and terms, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
Business/commercial establishments shall mean each person, firm, corporation or association licensed to do business in the City of Guntersville and having a location therein generating refuse including, but not limited to: nursing homes, schools, libraries, governmental organizations and buildings, hospitals, hotels, motels, bed and breakfasts, churches, marinas, or restaurants. 
City's contractor as the case may be, shall be taken to mean third parties to whom the City of Guntersville has contracted for the performance of any portion or all of the services otherwise to be rendered by the sanitation or public works departments as provided in the ordinance from which this article was derived, and shall also include persons authorized by the city to haul refuse within the City of Guntersville. 
Dumpster or special container shall mean a metal container of substantial construction and size suitable for garbage and refuse collection and disposal to be specially equipped for mechanical dumping of garbage and refuse into sanitation vehicles. 
Garbage/refuse includes all waste accumulations of animal, fruit or vegetable matter that attend the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storage of meat, fowl, fish, fruits, or vegetables and any other materials or substances, regardless of definition, presently collected by the sanitation department. 
Garbage can means a watertight receptacle of substantial construction having a capacity of not less than ten (10) nor more than thirty-two (32) gallons, with a tight-fitting lid or cover, with not less than one handle on the lid or cover, and two (2) handles on the receptacle, by which same may be conveniently lifted or moved. No garbage can in excess of thirty-two-gallon capacity or weighing over fifty (50) pounds will be serviced. 
Garbage dump means a place for dumping or disposing of refuse, operated by the City of Guntersville, Alabama or such other place as may be designated and approved by the county health officer of Marshall County, Alabama. 
Hazardous waste means any substance defined as a hazardous material by the Environmental Protection Agency or the State Department of Environmental Management. The four (4) properties that constitute hazardous waste are ignitability, corrosiveness, reactivity, and toxicity. 
Residential premises means any dwelling, flat, rooming house, apartment house, mobile home, or vessel with normal kitchen facilities and having water or electric service. 
Rubbish includes nonrotten organic matter, consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as yard waste, crockery, wood shavings, cloth and materials made up of metallic construction such as refrigerators, stoves, metal furniture, etc. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 2, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 1003, § 2, 10-18-10)  
Sec. 12-82. - Littering, sweepings, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep, throw or otherwise deposit or cause to be deposited any refuse or rubbish into or on any public street, alley, gutter, tunnel, sidewalk, park, lot vacant or occupied, or property which is in the possession of another person. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to permit or cause to be permitted any refuse or rubbish to accumulate in such manner that it may be carried and deposited into or on any of the above places by action of the rain, wind or snow. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to impede or cause to be impeded the flow of water in the gutters, along the streets, sidewalks or the storm drainage systems. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful to cause any refuse or rubbish to become an obstruction to traffic or pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 3, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 1003, § 3, 10-18-10)  
Sec. 12-83. - Unkempt premises as nuisance. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person in possession, charge or control of any premises to keep, or cause to be kept or allow the keeping on any premises of refuse in such manner that it will become offensive or deleterious to health or likely to cause disease, and the same is hereby declared a public nuisance. 
(b)  The county health officer, his authorized representatives, the superintendent of sanitation or such other fully authorized inspectors as may be designated by the governing body are hereby authorized to inspect any premises for the purpose of seeing that the requirements of this chapter are being complied with, and it shall be unlawful for any person whomsoever to resist or interfere with such representative by work, deed or act in the performance of such inspection. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 4, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 1003, § 4, 10-18-10)  
Sec. 12-84. - Collection of building debris, dirt, stumps, tree trunks from private property. 
(a)  The city shall not be responsible for the collecting or hauling of rubbish, trash, limbs, brush or other debris from private property preliminary to, during or subsequent to construction of whatever type prior to occupancy. Said material shall be removed by the owner of said property or the contractor responsible for the accumulation of the same. 
(b)  Building debris such as scrap lumber, plaster, roofing, concrete, brickbats, sheetrock, shingles and sanding dust resulting from the construction, repair or remodeling of any building or appurtenances on private property, will not be removed by the public works department or the city's contractor. The owner must remove or cause to be removed by private contractor this waste within seven (7) days upon receipt of notice from the public works department. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of all fence companies, tree surgeons, nurseries, and landscape contractors or any individual or company doing work on private property to remove from premises all residues and rubbish resulting from said work. 
(d)  Reserved for schedule/charges in case we can provide rolloff service. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 5, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 1003, § 5, 10-18-10)  
Sec. 12-85. - Animals. 
(a)  Dead animals will be picked up by the sanitation department. In no event shall any person having a dead animal on premises occupied or under the control of such person allow it to remain undisposed of for a period of longer than twelve (12) hours. In the event the dead animals must be disposed of on a day other than the regular designated collection day, the sanitation department shall be notified. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of places of business making a business of treating, handling, keeping or disposing of animals to remove all dead animals from their premises to a designated dump site. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 6, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 1003, § 6, 10-18-10)  
Sec. 12-86. - Use of garbage cans for disposal of garbage. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person in possession, charge or control of any premises where garbage is created or accumulated and in case of multiple dwellings, multiple occupancy, trailer parks or marinas the owner of the premises, at all times to keep or cause to be kept a sufficient number of garbage cans (at least one garbage can for each family or other unit but not to exceed three (3) cans per family) for the deposit therein, and lids or cover of such garbage cans shall be kept tightly closed at all times other than when garbage is being deposited therein or removed therefrom. 
(b)  Garbage cans and dumpsters used for the deposit of garbage for collection by the city sanitation department or the city's contractor shall be in good condition so that collection therefrom shall not injure the person collecting the contents thereof. Cans or dumpsters having ragged, sharp edges, rusted bottoms or other defects or not meeting the standard size requirements must be promptly replaced or repaired upon the receipt of notice from the sanitation department and if not so replaced or repaired within ten (10) days of receipt of such notice, such nonconforming or defective cans may be collected by the sanitation department and disposed of as waste. Defective dumpsters may be repaired and reasonable cost of repairs assessed to the owner. 
(c)  Subject to the approval of the superintendent of the sanitation department, persons charged in this section with the duty of providing suitable receptacles may arrange for the refuse to be deposited in dumpsters or special containers, approved by the superintendent or his agent. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 7, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 1003, § 7, 10-18-10)  
Sec. 12-87. - Placement of containers. 
(a)  All garbage cans and approved dumpsters to be emptied by the sanitation department or the city's contractor shall be placed at places to be determined by the sanitation department. Garbage will be collected on the days and between the hours designated by said department. 
(b)  All garbage cans and approved dumpsters shall be situated so that they cannot be overturned by wind or animals. 
(c)  All garbage cans and approved dumpsters shall be placed and maintained so as to be fully accessible and convenient to workers emptying the same, and so as to accommodate the equipment used in the performance of such service. 
(d)  Where garbage collections are made from private alleys and access ways, said approaches shall be maintained in such a manner as not to be a hazard to sanitation personnel or equipment. 
(e)  No garbage, rubbish or other solid waste shall be picked up inside of any dwelling garage, porch, patio, carport or fenced area of any residence, commercial business or industrial establishment, except as provided for in subsection (h) as listed below. 
(f)  All vicious animals shall either be confined or garbage receptacles placed at a point where collectors may empty same without attack from said animals. 
(g)  It shall be the duty of any person planning to construct any apartment house, multiple unit, business place or industrial building to submit plans showing the location of garbage cans or dumpsters and/or pickup points for the approval of the sanitation department prior to obtaining a building permit. 
(h)  In the event the property owner locates a dumpster or container visible from any street, roadway, etc., and said dumpster is deemed to be unsightly the property owner may be required to build a fence or enclosure for the dumpster. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 8, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 1003, § 8, 10-18-10)  
Sec. 12-88. - Public trash receptacles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or cause to be removed from any street or sidewalk in the city any receptacle furnished by the city for the deposit of trash. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sit upon or deface any such receptacle or dumpster of cause it to be used in any way which will make it not accessible for the receipt of trash. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place trash or any other material near any such receptacle or dumpster, in such manner as to interfere with or preclude the use of any such receptacle, for the purpose which it is intended to serve. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 9, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 1003, § 9, 10-18-10)  
Sec. 12-89. - Removing garbage from cans or dumpsters. 
It shall be unlawful for any person other than those removing the entire contents thereof for disposal, to remove any garbage or other like materials from any garbage can or dumpster after it has been placed therein. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 10, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 1003, § 10, 10-18-10)  
Sec. 12-90. - Pick-up of leaves, shrubbery, and bulky waste. 
(a)  Leaves and grass clippings shall be bagged and placed for pickup on the collection day determined by the public works department. During the period October first to May first of each year, leaves and grass clippings in quantities greater than three (3) bags may be placed in a loose pile at the edge of the owners property, in no instance shall leaves or grass clippings be placed on public right-of way or a city street, nor shall they be placed in a city gutter, ditch or alley. 
(b)  Shrubbery clippings, limbs, bulky waste, and other small miscellaneous vegetation including garden vegetation, may be placed in a loose pile at the edge of the owners property, in no instance shall the materials be placed on public right-of-way or city street, nor shall they be placed in a city gutter, ditch or alley. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place for collection any icebox, refrigerator or other container, including garbage or trash containers large enough to enclose a human being, which have a snap lock or other device thereon, without first removing said snap lock or doors, or without providing a device which will allow the door or doors to be operated from the inside of said container. 
(d)  Rubbish deposited in fifty-five-gallon drums will be picked up only on a special call to the public works department. These drums will be picked up on a special truck and will not be returned. 
(e)  Additional pickup over normal service could be subject to additional charge. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 11, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 1003, § 11, 10-18-10)  
Sec. 12-91. - Charges for collection from residences. 
(a)  Residential/household solid waste, garbage, refuse collection will be one time per week at each residence at a rate established by the ordinance from which this article was derived of fourteen dollars ($14.00) per month. 
(b)  Mobile homes or trailers, whether located in a designated park or situated on a private plat of property, shall be considered as an individual residence and the rate for solid waste, garbage or refuse collection for each shall be established by the ordinance from which this article was derived of fourteen dollars ($14.00) per month for each. 
(c)  Each apartment or unit of multiple occupancy shall be considered as an individual residence and the rate for solid waste, garbage or refuse collection for each shall be established by the ordinance from which this article was derived of fourteen dollars ($14.00) per month for each unit. 
(d)  Boats or vessels with usual and normal kitchen facilities shall be considered as an individual dwelling and the rate for solid waste, garbage, or refuse collection for each shall be established by the ordinance from which this article was derived of fourteen dollars ($14.00) per month for each unit. 
(e)  All bills for service shall be rendered monthly on the same statement rendered by the water board for water service. In the event water service is not available, the water board will prepare a billing for sanitation services based on listing for electric services. 
(1)  Each resident shall pay the established rate for one month prior to commencement of services. 
(2)  Each bill shall be due when rendered and shall become delinquent if not paid within ten (10) days thereafter. If any such bill shall not be paid within five (5) days after it becomes delinquent, both the furnishing of water service and refuse service shall thereupon be discontinued to the dwelling. 
(f)  The Guntersville Water Board is hereby designated as the agent for collection of said sanitation fees. 
(1)  The water department shall remit the sanitation fees to the city clerk each month. 
(2)  The water department each month shall submit a listing of each billing showing amount paid and any balance of sanitation fees that may be delinquent. 
(3)  The city clerk or designated agent is hereby authorized to collect any delinquent fees. 
(4)  The mayor and city council shall determine the disposition of any uncollectable fees. 
(g)  Failure to pay the charges herein provided shall constitute a violation of this chapter and shall be unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 12, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 1003, § 12, 10-18-10)  
Sec. 12-92. - Garbage service for business establishments. 
(a)  The minimum commercial rate for each business, generating less than two (2) cubic yards of solid waste per week on a one-time per week collection schedule, shall be established by the ordinance from which this article was derived at thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per month. In the event pickups beyond the scheduled service become necessary, additional charges of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per each extra pickup are to be billed. 
(b)  Upon every person operating a business establishment generating garbage in excess of two (2) cubic yards per week, a service fee per month per business establishment shall be determined by the following schedule. Business establishment classified as restaurants, lounges, manufacturers of grain feeds, distributors of feed and feed ingredients, and other concerns such as may be determined by the superintendent of sanitation to generate solid waste in excess of normal weights established for dumpsters, the service fee per month shall be listed in the following schedule as excessive weight.
