Sec. 13-121. - [Prohibited hunting area established.] 
A prohibited hunting area of Lake Guntersville is hereby established within the city limits and the police jurisdiction of the City of Guntersville, Alabama. This area where hunting is prohibited on Lake Guntersville is defined as the area lying inside the lines created by connection of the following GPS coordinates: 
Point 1: 	N 34º.36 	  
	W 86º.26 	
Point 2: 	N 34º.22 	
	W 86º.18 	
Point 3: 	N 34º.19 	
	W 86º.20 	
Point 4: 	N 34º.34 	
	W 86º.25 	
Point 5: 	N 34º.30 	
	W 86º.34 	
Point 6: 	N 34º.31 	
	W 86º.30 	
Point 7: 	N 34º.34 	
	W 86º.25 	
 
(Ord. No. 1030, § 1, 9-17-12)  
Sec. 13-122. - [Unlawful to hunt in prohibited area.] 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to hunt, trap, shoot or attempt to shoot or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl within the prohibited hunting area of Lake Guntersville described herein. 
(Ord. No. 1030, § 2, 9-17-12)  
Sec. 13-123. - [Unlawful to hunt within one hundred yards of dwelling; exceptions.] 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to hunt, trap, shoot or attempt to shoot or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl within one hundred (100) yards of any dwelling without the permission of the owner or lessee or discharge a firearm while hunting so that any projectile strikes any dwelling or building used for human occupation, or any commercial vessel, without the permission of the owner or lessee. This prohibition shall not apply to a landowner or member of his/her immediate family hunting on his/her own property provided that no projectile strikes the above property of another without the permission of the owner or lessee. 
(Ord. No. 1030, § 3, 9-17-12)  
Sec. 13-124. - [Penalty for violation of article.] 
Violation of this article shall be punishable by a fine up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) and up to thirty (30) days in jail for each violation. 
Each violation of this article shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1030, §§ 4, 5, 9-17-12)  
Secs. 13-125—13-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - REGULATION OF SHORT-TERM RENTAL DWELLINGS IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS 
 
Sec. 13-131. - Regulations. 
The following regulations apply to short-term rental of dwellings in districts zoned residential in the city limits. These regulations do not apply in districts in which commercial lodging is permitted. 
(1)  For purposes of this article, "short-term rental" (STR) means the rental of a dwelling unit for less than thirty (30) consecutive days per rental period and the rental unit itself. 
(2)  The property owner of the STR must have a renting and leasing business license from the city before a property owned by the property owner can be advertised or operated for STR. In addition the property owner must submit a STR annual permit application to the city and obtain and maintain a STR annual permit for each STR unit at a cost of twenty dollars ($20.00) per permit per year. 
(3)  The property owner must provide with the STR permit application the name, address and telephone number of an emergency contact that will respond within one (1) hour to complaints about the condition or operation of the STR or conduct of renters or their guests. The emergency contact must be able to respond on-site within twelve (12) hours if requested by the city. The emergency contact must answer calls twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week for the duration of each short-term rental period. Prior to any change to the emergency contact, the owner must submit the revised contact information to the city building official. 
(4)  The STR may only be rented for lodging use. The STR may not be rented for weddings, parties, concerts or similar events or used for such events during any short-term rental period. 
(5)  Insurance . All STR owners must obtain and maintain vacation rental property insurance that covers the lodging use of the site. Proof of insurance must be provided within thirty (30) days of the issuance of the STR permit. Proof of insurance must be resubmitted each year for renewal of the STR permit. 
(6)  Occupancy . The dwelling may not be rented to more than one (1) party simultaneously. Occupancy is limited to no more than two (2) persons plus two (2) persons per bedroom. To be considered a bedroom, the room must meet the minimum requirements of the International Building Code adopted by the city as it pertains to a bedroom. 
(7)  The number of bedrooms are to be determined by the city building official as part of the STR permit application process. The city building official may inspect the dwelling to verify information submitted with the STR permit application. 
(8)  The property owner must, by written agreement with the renter, limit overnight occupancy of the STR to the maximum occupancy approved with the STR permit. 
(9)  No on-premises signage legible from any right-of-way may advertise the STR. 
(10)  The STR property owner and all occupants of the STR must comply with all applicable city ordinances and regulations including, but not limited to, building construction, fire safety, noise, mandatory recycling and garbage collection and disposal. 
(11)  The STR must have adequate off-street parking to accommodate all occupant parking needs. All occupant vehicles must park off the street and on the STR property. No recreational vehicles, buses, boats or trailers may be stored on the street or forward of the front property line of the STR property. 
(12)  No food may be prepared or served to rental occupants by the STR property owner. 
(13)  A copy of this article, the STR permit, emergency contact information and house rules that comply with this article must be posted in a conspicuous place in the STR. The STR rental party must sign a document indicating it received all of these documents. 
(14)  Upon notification that a renter or a renter's guest has violated any provisions of this article or any noise, garbage or other provisions of city ordinances and regulations, the STR owner or emergency contact must promptly notify the renter of the violation and take such action as is necessary to prevent a reoccurrence. 
(15)  Notice . Each owner must, upon issuance of an STR permit or upon changes to an existing STR permit, provide written notice to all owners of residentially zoned property who own property adjacent to the STR property, which notice includes the following information: 
a.  The names and telephone numbers of the owner and emergency contact (if not the owner). 
b.  The city telephone number by which members of the public may report violations. 
c.  The maximum number of renters permitted to stay in the unit. The permit application shall include the name and address of all property owners who own residential property adjacent to the STR property. 
(16)  Taxation . The property owner is responsible for collecting and reporting taxes from any rental arrangement that is not subject to an established collection agreement with the city. 
(17)  Garbage fees and garbage container storage . The property owner is responsible for paying an additional rate as set forth by the city for any garbage containers exceeding two (2) thirty-two-gallon containers. In addition all garbage containers shall be stored out of sight of the street on the days not scheduled for garbage pickup by the city. 
(18)  Definition of vehicles . Vehicles shall include cars, trucks, and motorcycles and off road vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 1097, § 1, 12-3-18)  
Sec. 13-132. - Violations. 
The following procedures shall apply in the event a violation of this article occurs: 
(1)  If, after investigation, the city determines that any provisions of this article have been violated, the city will notify the property owner in writing stating the provisions violated, necessary corrective action and a compliance due date, as applicable. In addition the city will use best efforts to immediately contact the property owner or emergency contact by telephone of any reported violation. Upon receipt of notice by telephone, the property owner or emergency contact shall have the obligation to immediately contact the renter concerning such violation and request the renter to immediately take action in order to end the violation. Any violations of this article by renters shall be considered a violation by the property owner. 
(2)  Fines . In addition to the other remedies set out in this section, violations will be subject to fines as follows: 
a.  Violation warning . The city may, in an exercise of discretion, issue a warning to the person responsible for the violation if that person has not been previously warned or cited for violating a provision of this article. 
b.  First violation . The first time a person is found to have violated one (1) of the provisions of this article, the person is subject to a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
c.  Second and subsequent violations . Any second or subsequent time a person is found to have violated the provisions of this article, the person is subject to a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each subsequent violation. 
(3)  If a violation of building, fire safety or property maintenance regulations has not been corrected by the compliance date, the city may cause the STR permit to be temporarily suspended. When a first time violation has been corrected, the permit shall be re-instated for the remainder of its current approval period. The city may approve an extension of the compliance date if substantial progress toward compliance has been made provided that the public will not be adversely affected by the extension. 
(4)  Recurring violations . When noise, occupancy, parking, trespass or other violations concerning the conduct at the STR or by its renters or their guests are found to have occurred more than once in the same license year or within any six-month period, or if a fine assessed against a STR property owner is not paid within thirty (30) days of delivery of notice of the fine, the city may set a hearing before the city council for the revocation of the permit related to that STR as to which a violation has occurred. 
(5)  If the holder of the STR permit disagrees with the finding of a violation by the city, the STR permit holder may request a hearing before the city council on the decision of the city. Following a public hearing on the matter, the city council may find in favor of the STR permit holder thereby eliminating any penalties assessed against the permit holder or the city council may confirm the city's decision and confirm the penalties assessed against the permit holder pursuant to this article including revocation of the STR permit. 
(6)  Written notice of any fines and hearings on violations and permit revocations shall be delivered to the property owner. Notice of hearings shall be given at least ten (10) days before the hearing. Notice shall be deemed delivered when placed in the U.S. mail to the address listed on the permit application. 
(7)  Any person, who disagrees with the decision of the city council, shall have the right to appeal de novo to the Circuit Court of Marshall County, Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 1097, § 2, 12-3-18)  
Chapter 14 - PERSONNEL  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 14-1—14-19. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - POLICE 
 
Sec. 14-20. - System established; merit principles. 
There is hereby established a personnel system for the police department of the city. Such system shall be established on the following merit principles: 
(1)  Recruiting, selecting and advancing employees on the basis of their relative ability, knowledge, and skills, including open competition of qualified applicants for initial appointments; 
(2)  Establishing pay rates consistent with the principle of providing comparable pay for comparable work; 
(3)  Training employees, as needed to assure high quality performance; 
(4)  Retaining employees on the basis of the adequacy of their performance, correcting inadequate performance and separating employees whose inadequate performance can not be corrected; 
(5)  Assuring fair treatment of applicants and employees in all aspects of personnel administration without regard to political affiliation, race, color, creed, national origin, ancestry, sex or religion. 
(Ord. No. 494, § 1, 8-22-77)  
Sec. 14-21. - Classified service, exceptions. 
The classified service shall include all employees serving in continuing positions in the police department of the city except the following: 
(1)  Members of the municipal governing body and other elected officials; 
(2)  Members of appointed boards and commissions, municipal judges and municipal attorneys; 
(3)  Persons employed to work less than full-time; 
(4)  Administrative officials appointed by the mayor and/or governing body, including the police chief; 
(5)  Volunteer personnel who receive no regular compensation from the municipality; 
(6)  Temporary positions scheduled for less than one (1) year's duration unless specifically covered by the action of the mayor and council; 
(7)  Persons performing work under contract for the municipality who are not carried on the payroll as employees. 
Nothing herein shall be construed as precluding the mayor or governing body from filling any excepted positions in the manner in which positions in the classified service are filled. 
(Ord. No. 494, § 2, 8-22-77)  
Sec. 14-22. - Personnel officer—Designated; assistance. 
The city clerk is hereby designated to perform the duties of personnel officer. The city clerk may have other staff members designated to assist or may designate any member of such clerk's staff to assist. 
(Ord. No. 494, § 3, 8-22-77)  
Sec. 14-23. - Same—Duties. 
The personnel officer shall be responsible for the personnel administration system and shall direct all of its administrative and technical activities. Such officer's duties shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Encourage and exercise leadership in the development of effective personnel administration practices within the municipality; 
(2)  Investigate from time to time the operation and, effect of this article and the policies made thereunder and to report such officer findings and recommendations to the mayor and governing body; 
(3)  Establish and maintain comprehensive personnel records for each employee in the police department including for each employee such employee's classification, pay rate, date of employment, and other relevant data; 
(4)  Advise the mayor and governing body on matters affecting the most effective use of manpower resources; 
(5)  Make an annual report to the mayor and governing body regarding the status of the personnel administration program. 
(Ord. No. 494, § 4, 8-22-77)  
Sec. 14-24. - Same—Preparation of personnel rules and regulations. 
The personnel officer shall draft or cause to be drafted the personnel rules and regulations for the police department. Such rules shall become effective upon passage of an appropriate ordinance by the governing body. The policies shall provide for: 
(1)  The classification of all positions, based on duties, authority and responsibility of each position, with adequate provisions for reclassification of any positions warranted by changed circumstances; 
(2)  A pay plan for classified service positions; 
(3)  Announcement of employee vacancies and acceptance of application for employment; 
(4)  Preparation and administration of examinations, if appropriate; 
(5)  Establishment and use of eligibility lists, if appropriate; 
(6)  Establishment of promotion policies and procedures; 
(7)  Transfer, promotion and reinstatement of employees; 
(8)  Performance evaluations of employees, including those on probationary periods; 
(9)  Separation of employees from the classified service by resignation, suspension, dismissal, layoff, or incapacity to perform required duties; 
(10)  Grievance and appeal procedures; 
(11)  Establishment of hours of work, holidays, vacations, leave regulations and procedures; 
(12)  Outside employment of municipal employees of the police department; 
(13)  Establishment of a probation period for all employees prior to final appointment; 
(14)  Development of employee morale, safety and training programs; 
(15)  Such other matters as may be necessary to carry out the intent and purpose of this article. 
(Ord. No. 494, § 5, 8-22-77)  
Sec. 14-25. - Same—Payroll verification. 
The personnel officer or such officer's authorized agent shall be responsible for the certification of the payroll vouchers that the persons named therein have been appointed and employed in accordance with the provisions of this article and the policies thereunder. The disbursing officer of the municipality shall not make or approve or take part in making or approving any payment for the personal service to any person holding a position in the municipality unless such payroll voucher or account of such pay bears the certification of the personnel officer or such officer's authorized agent. 
(Ord. No. 494, § 6, 8-22-77)  
Sec. 14-26. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 701A, adopted Feb. 21, 1994, repealed former § 14-26, which pertained to the establishment, powers and duties, and compensation of the police administrator.  
Sec. 14-27. - Storage and record of abandoned and/or stolen property. 
(a)  Abandoned and stolen property found within the corporate city limits of the city or within the police jurisdiction for the city and taken in possession by the city police department shall be stored in properly secured spaces to protect it from loss or deterioration. 
(b)  Perishable property may be sold at once without notice, in which case the proceeds shall be held for a period of six (6) months for the account of the owner and if not called for within that time shall be converted into the general fund. 
(c)  A permanent record giving the date of the taking of each piece of such property, the place where found and taken and a description of the property shall be kept. 
(Ord. No. 1096, § 1, 9-7-18)  
Sec. 14-28. - Disposal and sale of abandoned and/or stolen property; notice requirements. 
(a)  At least every six (6) months, the police chief shall sell at public auction to the highest bidder for cash the abandoned and stolen property having been stored for a period of three (3) months or more. 
(b)  The sales are to be made after notice of the time and place has first been given by publication of notice once a week for two (2) successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation published in the city. Should no such newspaper be published, such notice shall be given by posting in a conspicuous place at the city hall or police station. The first publication, or posting of notice, as the case may be, shall be at least twenty (20) days before the sale. 
(c)  The owner of any stored, abandoned or stolen property may redeem such property at any time prior to its sale by demonstrating bona fide proof of ownership, and by paying a reasonable cost of possession, maintenance and storage having been absorbed by the police department. 
(d)  Each article shall be sold separately and a notation in the storage record book or data base shall be made to the amount received for each article. 
(e)  The police chief, or his representative, shall have the right to reject any and all bids if the amount of bid be unreasonably low and shall have the right to continue the sales from time to time if no bidders are present. 
(f)  After deducting and paying expenses incurred in the possession, storing, maintaining and selling of the property, the balance, if any, shall be paid into the general fund of the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 1096, § 2, 9-7-18)  
Secs. 14-29—14-39. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SOCIAL SECURITY 
 
Sec. 14-40. - Declaration of coverage. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, effective as of January 1, 1955, to the employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law or by this article, and whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function, the benefits of the system of old age and survivor's insurance as authorized by the federal social security act and amendments thereto, including Public Law 734 of 81st Congress, and Public Law 761 of the 83rd Congress, second session. In pursuance of such policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 325B, § 1, 1-11-55)  
Sec. 14-41. - Execution of agreements. 
The mayor or other chief executive officer of the city is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the state agency authorized to act to secure coverage of employees and officials as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 325B, § 2, 1-11-55)  
Sec. 14-42. - Withholdings. 
Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided in this article are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state and federal laws and regulations, and shall be paid over to the state or federal agency designated by such laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Ord. No. 325B, § 3, 1-11-55)  
Sec. 14-43. - Contributions. 
There shall be appropriated from available funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state and federal laws and regulations for employers' contributions, which shall be paid over to the state agency designated by such laws and regulations to receive same. 
(Ord. No. 325B, § 4, 1-11-55)  
Sec. 14-44. - Records and reports. 
The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state and federal laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 325B, § 5, 1-11-55)  
Sec. 14-45. - Adoption of laws; excluded officials and employees. 
The city does hereby adopt the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges, and other conditions thereunto appertaining, of title II of the Social Security Act as amended, for and on behalf of all the officers and employees thereof, excepting any official or employee who occupies any position, office, or employment not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations; and further excluding: 
(1)  Elected officials, and 
(2)  Officials or employees whose compensation is on a fee basis. 
(Ord. No. 325B, § 6, 1-11-55)  
Chapter 15 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B. 
 
Sec. 15-1. - City planning commission—Created. 
In order to guide and accomplish a comprehensive and coordinated development of the city which will promote the health, safety, convenience, prosperity, and general welfare of the citizens thereof, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, and to insure the orderly and systematic arrangement and development of future public works projects, there is hereby created a city planning commission, hereinafter referred to as the "commission," pursuant to the Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-2. 
(Ord. No. 237, § 1, 6-3-40)  
Sec. 15-2. - Same—Members. 
(a)  The commission shall consist of nine (9) members, namely the mayor or the mayor's duly appointed representative, one (1) of the administrative officials of the city selected by the mayor and a member of the city council to be selected by it, as members ex-officio, and six (6) persons, who shall be appointed by the mayor. 
(b)  All members of the commission shall serve as such without compensation, and the appointed members shall hold no other municipal office, except that one (1) of such appointed members may be a member of the zoning board of adjustments and appeals. 
(c)  The term of the ex-officio members shall correspond to their respective official tenures, except that the term of the administrative official selected by the mayor shall terminate with the term of the mayor selecting such official. The term of each appointed member shall be six (6) years or until a successor takes office, except that the respective terms of five (5) of the members first appointed shall be one (1), two (2), three (3), four (4), and five (5) years. 
(d)  Members other than the member selected by the council may, after a public hearing, be removed by the mayor for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office. The council may for like cause remove the member selected by it. The mayor or council, as the case may be, shall file a written statement of reasons for such removal. 
(e)  Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of term shall be filled for the unexpired term by mayor in the case of members selected or appointed by the mayor, and by the council in the case of the councilmanic member. 
(Ord. No. 237, § 1, 6-3-40)  
Sec. 15-3. - Same—Organization and rules. 
The commission shall elect its chairman from amongst the appointed members and create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine. The term of the chairman shall be one (1) year, with eligibility for reelection. The commission shall hold at least one (1) regular meeting in each month. It shall adopt rules for transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings, and determinations, which record shall be a public record. 
(Ord. No. 237, § 1, 6-3-40)  
Sec. 15-4. - Same—Powers and duties. 
(a)  The commission shall have all the powers given and duties imposed upon a municipal planning commission as set forth and prescribed in the Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-6 et seq. 
(b)  The commission shall act as the zoning commission for the city, and shall have all the powers and perform all the duties of a municipal zoning commission as set forth and prescribed by law. 
(Ord. No. 237, § 4, 6-3-40)  
Sec. 15-5. - Same—Reports. 
The commission shall make an annual written report at the close of each fiscal year to the mayor and council covering its investigations, transactions, and recommendations, and such other reports relative thereto as it may deem proper or as requested by the council. 
(Ord. No. 237, § 5, 6-3-40)  
Sec. 15-6. - Violation of commission rules and regulations. 
Any person violating any reasonable rule or regulation promulgated and adopted by the commission, or who transfers or sells, or aids in transferring or selling any lands in violation of law shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 237, § 6, 6-3-40)  
Chapter 16 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Tree commission, § 2-15 et seq.; restoration of surface after excavations, §§ 12-1(c), 12-2(d), 12-3(d); attaching advertisement on street, etc., § 12-58. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 16-1. - Building numbers—To be assigned; specifications; cost; posting. 
(a)  There shall be assigned to each house and other building on land abutting any street, avenue, alley or highway in the city, its respective number under the uniform system adopted by the city. When each house or other building has been assigned its respective number, the owner or occupant shall place or cause to be placed upon each house or other building and/or both sides of a curb-mounted mailbox controlled by such person the number assigned under the uniform system. 
(1)  Such numbers shall be placed or, if missing, replaced within twenty (20) days after the assigning of the proper number. The cost of such numbers shall be paid for by the property owners or occupants. 
(2)  The standard minimum height of the numbers, for all houses and buildings, is three (3) inches. 
(3)  Single-family and duplex dwellings built and approved for occupancy before November 1, 1987, may continue to use numbers two and one-half (2½) inches in height. 
(b)  The numbers shall be conspicuously placed so that they can be seen plainly and be read from the street. Further: 
(1)  With single-family or duplex dwellings, the numbers shall be placed immediately above, on or at the side of the door or alongside the pathway to the door, and/or on both sides of a curb-mounted mailbox. 
(2)  With multiple-family dwellings, the numbers shall be placed on the building face most visible from the street or alley adjacent thereto. 
(3)  With commercial buildings whose public entrance is visible from the street, the numbers shall be placed above, on, or at the side of the door of each individual business. If no public entrance is visible from the street, the building will be numbered on the side most visible from the street. 
(4)  Whenever any building is situated more than fifty (50) feet from the sidewalk line, the numbers of such buildings shall be conspicuously displayed on the owner's property at the sidewalk line, near the walk, driveway or common entrance to such building, and upon the gatepost, fence, post, both sides of a curb-mounted mailbox, or other appropriate place so as to be easily discernible from the sidewalk or street. 
(c)  All numbers shall be of a durable material with numbers in contrast to background color. 
(Ord. No. 615, § 1, 11-2-87)  
Sec. 16-2. - Same—New buildings. 
(a)  Whenever any house, or other building shall be erected or located in the city after the establishment of the uniform system of house and other building numbering, and in order to preserve the continuity and uniformity of numbers of the houses and other buildings it shall be the duty of the owner or builder to get the proper number assigned by the city clerk. Once the number has been assigned, it is the responsibility of the owner or the builder to procure the correct number, of the required size, and to immediately fasten the number, so assigned, upon the house or other building, as provided herein. 
(b)  No building permit shall be issued for any house, building or structure until the owner has been assigned an official number by the city clerk for the premises. Final approval of any structure erected, repaired, altered or modified after November 1, 1987 shall be withheld by the building inspector until permanent and proper numbers have been affixed to the structure. 
(Ord. No. 615, § 2, 11-2-87)  
Sec. 16-3. - Adoption of standards for accommodating utilities on streets. 
The city council, hereby formally adopts the state highway department standards for accommodating utilities on highway rights-of-way as standards (as written and future amendments thereto) for use by the city for accommodating utilities on roads and streets under the jurisdiction of the city on those roads and streets which have or will involve the expenditure of state or federal highway funds. 
(Ord. No. 450, 9-7-71)  
Sec. 16-4. - Excavation permit. 
No person shall dig into or take up any street or pavement in the city for the purpose of laying pipe lines, pole lines, power or telephone conduits, sewers, railway tubes, or for other similar purposes without first obtaining at a cost of five dollars ($5.00) the written permission of the city engineer and depositing with the city clerk a sum estimated by the city engineer to be sufficient to replace such street or pavement in as good condition as it was before but in no event less than fifty dollars ($50.00). Such deposit shall be on condition that it shall be forfeited to the city in the event such street or pavement is not within fifteen (15) days from the completion of the work, without cost of the city, placed in as good condition as it was before. 
(Ord. No. 441, § 1, 10-5-70) 
Cross reference— Barricades at excavations, § 12-58.  
Sec. 16-5. - Damaging or obstructing drainage ditches. 
It shall be unlawful for any person wilfully to fill in, damage or otherwise obstruct drainage ditches along the public streets, thoroughfares or highways in the city. 
(Ord. No. 402A, § 1, 11-9-65)  
Sec. 16-6. - Discharge of water onto sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for the owners or occupants of any buildings in the city to permit or cause to be deposited upon any of the sidewalks of the city, any water collecting on any of the buildings, either by permitting the same to run onto the sidewalks or to be thrown thereon from any gutter or down pipe or passageway leading from the roofs of any of such buildings onto any of the sidewalks of the city, but nothing in this section shall prevent the owners or occupants of any building from so constructing water spouts, gutters, or down pipes to their building as to convey such water through an opening underneath any sidewalk, provided it is so constructed as not to spread upon or over the sidewalks or pour thereon from such building. 
(Ord. No. 130, § 1, 11-5-28)  
Secs. 16-7—16-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TRANSPORTING ON 
 
Sec. 16-51. - Intent. 
The spilling of vehicle loads upon the public streets and other public ways of the City of Guntersville is a dangerous and blighting factor which damages, deteriorates and depreciates these public ways, as well as adjacent and surrounding property. The city council of the City of Guntersville, Alabama finds that the spilling of vehicle loads is a public nuisance and recognizes that appropriate measures must be taken to keep public streets, other public ways and adjacent and surrounding property free from debris and other materials spilling from vehicles. Debris and other materials spilling from vehicles pose a danger of physical injury and property damage to motorists, pedestrians and other inhabitants of the City of Guntersville and cause the proliferation of trash, garbage, litter, and other dangerous or unsanitary debris within the city. The prevention of the spilling of vehicle loads and the removal of spillage from streets is necessary to prevent proliferation of this problem. This article is enacted to protect, promote and preserve the safety and welfare of the citizens of Guntersville, Alabama, through the reduction, control and prevention of vehicle spillage within the City of Guntersville, Alabama. The council does not intend for this article to conflict with any existing state law. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 1, 8-18-97)  
Sec. 16-52. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this article, the following terms are defined as hereinafter set forth: 
City shall mean the City of Guntersville, Alabama, a municipal corporation organized under the laws of the State of Alabama. 
Construction and demolition materials shall mean lumber, roofing and sheathing, scraps, dirt, stone, brick, ceramic, rubble, broken concrete, plaster, conduit, pipe, wire, insulation, carpet padding, gutters, sheet rock, siding, hvac, or other similar material. 
Debris shall mean the remains of any material broken down and tracked onto any highway by any vehicle, including, but not limited to, dirt, gravel, mud, rocks, brush, and any other loose material. 
Garbage shall mean putrescence animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, storage, preparation, cooking, serving and consumption of food, including wastes from markets, storage facilities, or handling and sale of produce and other food products. 
Litter shall mean all solid waste that can be or is subject to being blown or carried from place to place by the elements, including, but not limited to, cigarette butts, refuse, waste material, garbage, dead animals or fowl, offal, paper, glass, cans, bottles, trash, scrap metal, debris, and any foreign substance of whatever kind description, and whether or not it is of value. 
Load shall mean any material put in, on or drawn by any vehicle for transport including, but not limited to, garbage, litter, trash, rubbish, refuse, loose material, debris, process and fill material, construction and demolition materials, yard waste, and any foreign substance of whatever kind and description, whether putrescible or nonputrescible, and whether or not it is of value. Loads shall not include people. 
Loose material shall mean any material that is hauled on, or by any vehicle that could spill, drop, sift, leak, blow or otherwise escape said vehicle including, but not limited to, garbage, litter, trash, rubbish, refuse, loose material, debris, process and fill materials, construction and demolition materials, yard waste, and any foreign substance of whatever kind and description, whether putrescible or nonputrescible, and whether or not it is of value. 
Person shall mean an individual, partnership, association, syndicate, company, firm, trust, corporation, government corporation, department, bureau, agency, business or any entity recognized by law. 
Process and fill materials shall mean all materials used for fill or that are the result of a specific process. This term includes, but is not limited to, rock, gravel (any aggregate), sand, dirt, asphalt, pug mix, brick, cinder blocks, coal, feed, cement, concrete, tar, petroleum products, liquid, and similar materials. 
Refuse shall mean all solid or semisolid waste resulting from industrial processes and manufacturing operations, such as food processing wastes, boiler and house cinders, wood, plastic, metal scraps and shaving, byproducts accumulated as a result of treatment of liquid waste, etc.; putrescible and nonputrescible animal and vegetable waste from the handling, storage and sale of produce and meats; street sweeping, dirt, leaves, catch basin dirt and contents of litter receptacles. This term includes, but is not limited to, garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleaning, dead animals or fowl, offal, abandoned motor vehicles, and solid market or industrial wastes. 
Rubbish shall mean nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, including, but not limited to, paper, cardboard, rags, cartons, wood, boxes, excelsior, cloth, furniture, bedding, leather, rubber, plastics, yard trimmings, leaves, glass, crockery, metals, metal cans, metal foils, metal furniture, mineral refuse, and similar materials. 
Special vehicle shall mean any vehicle specially manufactured to transport or draw a particular type of load which is used solely in strict accordance with the purpose for which the special vehicle was manufactured, and in order to accomplish this purpose, is designed either: 
(a)  Without solid sides or a tailgate; or 
(b)  So that the load will extend above a point four (4) inches below the top of the sides of the special vehicle; or 
(c)  So that a tarpaulin or confinement system cannot be rigged or the load covered, secured or sealed while still allowing the special vehicle to accomplish its purpose. Exceptions in this article related to special vehicles shall be narrowly construed so that a vehicle qualifying as a special vehicle under any one or more, but not all, of (a), (b), or (c) of this definition shall be exempt only from those requirements of this article which are inherent in the design and purpose of the special vehicle, as manufactured, but not from any other requirements of this article which are not inherent in the design and purpose of the special vehicle, as manufactured. 
Tarpaulin or confinement system shall mean a solid or semisolid cover or system placed and secured over open-topped vehicles to secure loads and of sufficient and appropriate size, structure and strength to prevent the dispersal of loads and loose material from the vehicle. A tarpaulin or confinement system may be constructed from any suitable material, including, but not limited to, canvas, polyethylene, rubberized cloth, netting, ropes, straps, chains, cables, and racks with a restraining or enclosing system. 
Trash shall mean any nonputrescible solid wastes including, but not limited to, yard clippings, leaves, wood, compost, tree limbs, tree trunks, furniture, bedding, appliances, paper, cardboard, plastics, wrappings, cans, tires and similar materials. 
Vehicle shall mean any devise in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon the highway, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationery rails or tracks. This term includes, but is not limited to, trucks, trailers and automobiles. This term includes special vehicles unless specifically denoted otherwise. 
Yard waste shall mean grass, leaves, yard trimmings, shrubbery clippings, trees, branches, palm fronds, and all other miscellaneous vegetation. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2, 8-18-97)  
Sec. 16-53. - Spilling vehicle loads prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, operate, or permit to operated, any vehicle upon the public streets or other public ways of the city, when such vehicle is so constructed, maintained, or loaded, that the vehicle's load or loose material is permitted to blow, spill, drop, bounce, fall, waste or otherwise escape from such vehicle upon the public streets or other public ways or adjacent or surrounding property. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 3, 8-18-97)  
Sec. 16-54. - Solid sides, tailgate and solid top or tarpaulin or confinement system required with exception for special vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul a load or loose material unless the vehicle has solid sides and a tailgate, and is further equipped with a solid top or so rigged that a tarpaulin or confinement system can be spread or secured tightly over the top of such vehicle and is further equipped with a tarpaulin or confinement system. Any one or more of the requirements imposed by this section shall not apply to a special vehicle. Each vehicle shall have signs painted on both doors, or, if the vehicle does not have doors, then, on both sides, of the vehicle indicating the correct name of the hauler and his telephone number. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 4, 8-18-97)  
Sec. 16-55. - Covering, securing, sealing of loads required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul a load or loose material, unless the vehicle is covered, secured, or sealed to the extent that there will be no loss or spillage during haulage to cause littering of streets or highways or cause a nuisance or a hazard to the public health. The requirement imposed by this section shall not apply to a special vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 5, 8-18-97)  
Sec. 16-56. - Securing of boat loads required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul a boat upon the public streets or other public ways of the city unless all food, cooler, trash, life jackets, vests, skis, ropes, fishing gear, other equipment, and loose material are stored and secured to prevent these items from blowing, spilling, dropping, bouncing, falling, wasting or otherwise escaping onto public streets or other public ways or adjacent and surrounding property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul or transport any animal in the confines of an open boat which is being transported along public streets or public right-of-ways. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 6, 8-18-97)  
Sec. 16-57. - Maximum load height imposed. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul a load or loose material in a vehicle which does not have a solid top unless the load or loose material remains at least four (4) inches below the top of the sides of such vehicle as measured at the front, back and side walls of the vehicle. The use of a tarpaulin or confining system on a vehicle shall not excuse any person from compliance with the provisions of this section. The requirement imposed by this section shall not apply to a special vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 7, 8-18-97)  
Sec. 16-58. - Tracking debris onto public streets or other public ways prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, operate, or permit to be operated, any vehicle upon the public streets or other public ways of the city unless said vehicle is free of debris and trash that could be tracked onto the public streets or other public ways of the city in such a manner as to: 
(a)  Cause a safety hazard; 
(b)  Create rough driving conditions; 
(c)  Impede the flow of water in gutters or along streets or that would tend to clog drains, ditches, or sewers; 
(d)  Create a nuisance from dust generated by driving over debris and trash which has been tracked onto the highway; or 
(e)  Create a likelihood of gravel, stone, other debris, or trash being thrown into the windshield of other vehicles. 
The requirements of this section shall not apply to the tracking of debris onto public streets and other public ways of the city if said public streets and public ways are part of a construction or maintenance work site. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 8, 8-18-97)  
Sec. 16-59. - Cleaning, washing, or removing waste material prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to clean, wash, dispose of or remove waste material from any vehicle upon the public streets or other public ways of the city. This shall include, but not be limited to, grain, feed, coal, cement, or garbage vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 9, 8-18-97)  
Sec. 16-60. - Clearing of streets by persons responsible for spills or tracking. 
Any person operating, or permitting to be operated, a vehicle or hauling a boat in violation of this article shall immediately cause the public street or other public way or surrounding and adjacent property to be cleared of spilled or tracked material so long as the person does not endanger himself or any other person. If traffic or other conditions are such that it would not be safe to remove the spilled or tracked material, then the person responsible for the spilled or tracked material shall immediately notify Guntersville Police Department and request assistance. The person responsible for spilled or tracked material shall bear the costs involved in the containment and removal of the spilled tracked material. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 10, 8-18-97)  
Sec. 16-61. - Exemptions. 
The following activities are exempt from the provisions of sections 16-53, 16-55 and 16-58 of this article: 
(a)  The deposit or spreading of sand or other substances, not otherwise expressly prohibited, on the streets of the city for the purpose of street construction, maintenance or repair, or a maintenance of utilities or the use of water or other substances in cleaning or maintaining public streets or public ways, when such acts are performed by a city, state or federal governmental entity or a contractor conducting such actions pursuant to valid contract with a city, state or federal governmental entity. Vehicles carrying loads or loose material covered by this subsection, while in transit to a work site, must satisfy all requirements and prohibitions of this article. 
(b)  The deposit of sand or other substances, not otherwise expressly prohibited, on the streets of the city for the purpose of increasing traction when such acts are performed by a city, state or federal governmental entity or a contractor conducting such actions pursuant to a valid contract with a city, state or federal governmental entity, or by motorists spreading sand from public receptacles. 
(c)  Vehicles hauling loads or loose material that have reached their final destination and are preparing to unload. Vehicles carrying loads or loose material covered by this subsection, while in transit to their final destination, must satisfy all requirements and prohibitions of this article. 
(d)  Vehicles hauling loads of brush, limbs and other loose materials that have been collected in an authorized door to door program. These vehicles should be equipped with specially designed lifting apparatus that can be positioned in such a manner as to prevent loads from spilling or otherwise being deposited on any city street and public right-of-way. 
In addition to the above exemptions the following activities shall be further exempt from the provisions of sections 16-54 and 16-55: 
(e)  Vehicles hauling tree stumps, however, persons responsible for vehicles loaded with stumps shall take reasonable measures and precautions to secure the load in such a manner as to prevent the load from posing a danger of physical injury or property damage. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 11, 8-18-97)  
Sec. 16-62. - Enforcement. 
The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the city police department. Any sworn officer of the Guntersville Police Department is empowered to issue citations to appear in municipal court to answer charges for violation of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 12, 8-18-97)  
Sec. 16-63. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates or fails or refuses to obey or comply with any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished, in addition to such other punishment as may be provided by the court, by minimum fines and penalties, for a first conviction of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or by imprisonment for not more than ten (10) days; for conviction of a second offense committed within one year after the date of the first offense, such person shall be punished by a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00) or by imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days or by both such fine and imprisonment; for conviction of a third or subsequent offense committed within one year after the date of the first offense, such person shall be punished by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for not more than three (3) months or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 13, 8-18-97)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 17-1. - State laws and rules and regulations adopted; penalties. 
(a)  In addition to all other provisions of law relating to the speed and operation of motor vehicles in the city, there are hereby adopted by the city all laws of the state and all rules and regulations of the state department of public safety pertaining to the control of traffic and motor vehicles on highways that are misdemeanors under the state laws and a violation of such laws, rules and regulations in the city or in the police jurisdiction thereof, shall be violations of this Code. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a class "C" misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or may be imprisoned in a municipal jail or sentenced to hard labor for the city for a period not exceeding ten (10) days; for a second such conviction within one (1) year thereafter, shall be punished by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or may be imprisoned in a municipal jail or sentenced to hard labor for the city for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days, or by both fine and imprisonment; upon a third or subsequent conviction within one (1) year after the first conviction, such person shall be punished by a fine of not more than four hundred dollars ($400.00) or may be imprisoned in a municipal jail or sentenced to hard labor for the city for a period not exceeding three (3) months, or by both fine and imprisonment.

Cross reference— Adoption of state offenses, § 13-1.  
Sec. 17-1.1. - Liability insurance required; violation. 
The city adopts the mandatory Liability Insurance Act, pursuant to Code of Ala. § 32-7A-1, et seq., to be included on the City of Guntersville Magistrates Schedule of Fines. This section authorizes the magistrates of the city to accept payments of any violations of this section pursuant to Rule 20 (C) Alabama Rules of Judicial Administration. 
Where a defendant decides to plead guilty before a magistrate or sends a citation by mail the fine amounts shall be: 
(1)  Upon presenting valid proof of insurance on date of citation the magistrate shall recommend to the judge to dismiss the case upon payment of traffic court cost. 
(2)  Where the defendant has obtained valid insurance after the date of citation, the fine shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) and traffic court cost. 
(3)  Where the defendant has no insurance the fine shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) and traffic court cost. 
(Ord. No. 886, 12-17-04)  
Sec. 17-2. - Blood alcohol test. 
In compliance with Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-192, the city does hereby designate the chemical analysis of the breath by use of the "Drager Alcotest" as the test to be administered by its officers approved by the state board of health pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-194, and such other tests approved in the future by the Alabama Department of Forensic Sciences and performed by approved officers according to methods approved in the future by the Alabama Department of Forensic Sciences, to determine the alcoholic content of the blood of any person lawfully arrested for any offense arising out of acts alleged to have been committed while the person was driving a motor vehicle on the public highways of the state, or on the public roads and streets of the city, or on private property within the police jurisdiction, to the extent allowed under state law, while under the influence of intoxicating liquor. 
(Ord. No. 475, 1-20-75; Ord. No. 1059, 12-15-14) 
State Law reference— Administering of blood alcohol test, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-192.  
Sec. 17-3. - Off-street reckless driving. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle as defined in Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-1-1.1, upon the grounds, roads, or drives of any public park, school, or church, or upon the grounds, roads, or drives of any private commercial establishment or private shopping center, or upon any private or public parking lot carelessly or heedlessly in wilful or wanton disregard of the rights or safety of others, or without due caution and circumspection and at a speed or in a manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property. Any person violating this section shall be guilty of the offense of off-street reckless driving and guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 2, 6-6-77)  
Sec. 17-3.1. - Driving through business property to avoid traffic control devices prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive any vehicle upon the streets or highways of the city, or within the city's police jurisdiction, at any intersection where gasoline filling stations or other business property is located, so as to cause such vehicle to cut the corners of any such intersection by passing over the space used in the operation of such filling station or other business property, and thereby avoid the traffic light or traffic signal at any such intersection, or so as to avoid stopping at any such intersection as is required by the laws of the city, or so as to avoid traveling at any such intersection over the usual lanes of traffic. 
(Ord. No. 975, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 17-4. - Speed limit generally. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than twenty-five (25) miles per hour on any street or alley not specifically mentioned or set out in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 6, 7-17-72)

(3)  On Alabama Highway 79 from the south city limits (MP 61-14), (KMP 97.52) northerly to Willow Beach Road, north, (MP 65.89), (KMP 105.16) a distance of 4.75 miles, 7.64 kilometers. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 1, 7-17-72; Ord. No. 501, § 1, 3-20-78; Ord. No. 747, § 1, 11-4-96)

Sec. 17-9. - Thirty-five-mph speed limit generally. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than thirty-five (35) miles per hour in the following listed zones:

(Ord. No. 501, §§ 2, 3, 3-20-78; Ord. No. 720, § 1, 9-5-95; Ord. No. 728, § 1, 12-18-95; Ord. No. 789, § 1, 7-20-98; Ord. No. 1019, 3-19-12)  
Sec. 17-10. - Thirty-five-mph speed limit for trucks. 
No person shall operate a truck, herein defined as all buses, single unit trucks and truck combinations having a gross vehicle weight of nine thousand (9,000) pounds or greater, at a speed greater than thirty-five (35) miles per hour in the following listed zones: 
(1)  In the northbound lane of U.S. Highway No. 431 from a point 500 feet south of Pleasant Grove Road to Wyeth Drive. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 13, 7-17-72; Ord. No. 515, § 3, 6-18-79)  
Sec. 17-11. - Thirty-mph speed limit. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a speed greater than thirty (30) miles per hour in the following listed zones: 
(1)  Alabama Highway No. 227 from milepost 49.68 to milepost 50.10 and from milepost 50.57 to milepost 50.95. 
(2)  Alabama Highway No. 227 from milepost 50.10 to milepost 50.57. 
(3)  On the eastside service road adjacent to A1 1 (US 431) beginning at the end of the exit ramp (MP 301.00), northerly along the service road to the end of the service road at Wyeth Drive (MP 301.45), a distance of 0.45 miles. 
(4)  On the westside service road adjacent to A1 1 (US 431) beginning at the high school exit (MP 301.30), northerly along the service road to the end of the service road at Wyeth Drive (MP 301.45), a distance of 0.15 miles. 
(Ord. No. 636, § 1(C), 1-16-89; Ord. No. 733-A, § 1, 3-18-96)  
Sec. 17-12. - Truck routes—Nine-thousand-pound trucks. 
(a)  Streets on which trucks prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a truck weighing over ten thousand (10,000) pounds gross vehicle weight on the following streets within the city: 
(1)  Lurleen B. Wallace Drive from Gunter Avenue to the intersection of Sunset Drive and Ringold Street. 
(2)  Ringold Street from the intersection of Gunter Avenue to the intersection of Lurleen B. Wallace Drive. 
(3)  Sunset Drive from the intersection of Lurleen B. Wallace Drive to the intersection of Willow Beach Road. 
(4)  Willow Beach Road from its intersection with Sunset Drive to Alabama Highway No. 79 South. 
(5)  Patterson Street from Gunter Avenue to the intersection of Sunset Drive. 
(b)  Exceptions: 
(1)  Subsection (a) shall not apply to the operation of trucks weighing in excess of ten thousand (10,000) pounds gross vehicle weight, where necessary to the conduct of business at a destination point, provided streets upon which traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection nearest the destination point. 
(2)  Subsection (a) shall not apply to any truck operated by the city in the carrying out of any governmental or proprietary function. 
(3)  The city shall cause all streets upon which truck traffic is prohibited to be clearly signposted to give notice that this section is in effect. 
(4)  No person shall be charged with violating the provisions of this section by reason of operating a truck upon a street wherein truck travel is prohibited unless appropriate signs are posted on such street. 
(Ord. No. 641, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-89)  
Sec. 17-13. - Same—Five-thousand-pound vehicles. 
All trucks and other vehicles with a gross vehicle weight of five thousand (5,000) pounds or more traveling in a northerly direction upon and along U.S. Highway No. 431 within the corporate limits of the city, between the crest of Sand Mountain and the Stockton Causeway shall travel only in the right lane of the northbound lanes of such highway. 
(Ord. No. 470, 3-21-74)  
Sec. 17-14. - One-way roadways. 
(a)  The segment of May Street between Gunter Avenue and Blount Avenue is hereby made a one-way street and vehicular traffic on such segment is hereby restricted and limited to vehicular traffic moving in an easterly direction on such segment of May Street. 
(b)  Blount Avenue lying north of May Street is hereby made a one-way street for use by vehicular traffic and to consist of two (2) or more lanes for the flow of traffic moving in a northerly direction to the old and new river bridges. 
(c)  Gunter Avenue, from its beginning at the river bridge and extending in a southerly direction is hereby made a one-way street for use by vehicular traffic and to consist of two (2) or more lanes of traffic moving in such southerly direction to the intersection of Gunter Avenue with May Street. 
(d)  The roadway located on the west side of U.S. Highway No. 431 and adjacent to the Guntersville High School, shall be a service road with vehicular traffic permitted only to travel along such roadway in a southerly direction, parallel to, but separate from, the south bound lanes of U.S. Highway No. 431. 
(e)  The speed limit for Riley Road, a public street in the City of Guntersville, Alabama, shall be set at fifteen (15) mph. 
(f)  All motor vehicles must yield to pedestrian traffic crossing Riley Road in that area specifically designated for the pedestrian crossing of Riley Road as indicated by traffic signs and the visually designated area on Riley Road. In the event there are pedestrians in the designated crossing area, all motor vehicles must come to a complete stop until such time as the designated area has no pedestrians crossing Riley Road. 
(g)  Between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. and 3:00 p.m. Monday through Friday motor vehicles entering Sunset Drive from Riley Road shall turn right only when public school is in session. 
(h)  Between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. and 2:00 to 3:00 p.m. on Monday through Friday motor vehicles entering Lusk Street from the parking lot of Guntersville Middle School shall turn right only when public school is in session. 
(i)  Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this subsections (e)—(i) of this section may be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction shall be fined an amount not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) or be imprisoned in the municipal jail for a period not exceeding ten (10) days or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(Ord. No. 467, § 1, 12-3-73; Ord. No. 487, §§ 2, 3, 4-4-77; Ord. No. 500, § 1, 3-6-78; Ord. No. 668, §§ 1, 2, 8-19-91; Ord. No. 1094, §§ 1—5, 3-19-18)  
Sec. 17-15. - Private display of flashing lights. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use or display any flashing red, blue, green, amber, clear or white light or any combination thereof or any other flashing light or combination of lights on any vehicle or structure, or on any portable or permanent sign unless such use is expressly authorized by a city, county or state law, or as may herein be provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or locate any flashing lights or lights of any color or combination of colors within ten (10) feet of the curbline or edge of any street, road or highway, or within ten (10) feet of the margin of any city right-of-way within the city limits or police jurisdiction of the city, such ten-foot distance to be measured perpendicularly to and horizontally from such curb or edge of the road, street or highway or margin of such right-of-way; further, no flashing light or any color or combination of colors shall be placed on such city property, or right-of-way by lawful authority of the city, state, county or federal government. 
(c)  The chief of police and the duly authorized members of the police department are hereby vested with the power and authority and it shall be their duty to supervise and regulate the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 489, §§ 2—4, 4-25-77)  
Sec. 17-16. - Unauthorized drivers subject to towing. 
(a)  Notwithstanding, any other provisions of law, and except as otherwise provided in this section, a motor vehicle is subject to impounding as a nuisance if it is driven on a highway or other public roadway in the city if the motor vehicle is driven by a person whose license or license privilege is suspended, revoked or cancelled at the time he or she was stopped or involved in an accident. 
(b)  If a driver is unable to produce a valid drivers license on the demand of a law enforcement officer, the vehicle shall be impounded regardless of ownership, unless the officer is reasonably able, by other means to verify that the driver is properly licensed. Prior to impounding the vehicle the law enforcement officer shall make a reasonable attempt to verify the license status of a driver who claims to be properly licensed, but who is unable to produce the license on demand of the officer. A notation of the officer's attempt to verify that the driver is properly licensed shall be noted on the impound report. The driver and occupants of the vehicle will be transported to a place of safety by the impounding officer and an impound report made with a full inventory of items in the vehicle. 
(c)  A law enforcement officer shall not impound a vehicle pursuant to this section if the license of the driver expired within the preceding ninety (90) days and the driver would otherwise have been properly licensed. 
(d)  If the owner of the vehicle or another family member of the owner is present in the vehicle and has a valid license, the vehicle shall not be impounded and towed. 
(e)  If there is a medical necessity jeopardizing life or limb, the law enforcement officer may elect not to impound the vehicle. 
(f)  A vehicle impounded pursuant to this section shall be released if: 
(1)  The registered owner or a representative with written authorization from the registered owner appears at the city police department and presents a valid driver's license, a copy of the title, tag receipt, or notarized bill of sale. 
(2)  If the registered owner does not have a valid driver's license he or she may bring someone with them who has a valid license and the vehicle may be released without written notarized permission. 
(3)  Any owner of a vehicle who suffers any loss due to the impoundment of any vehicle pursuant to this section may recover the amount of the loss from the unlicensed, suspended, or revoked driver. 
(4)  The person redeeming the vehicle at the wrecker lot will be responsible for paying the set towing and storage fee. 
(5)  Any vehicle impounded that is not redeemed pursuant to this section within sixty (60) days may be sold by the wrecker company for fees owed according to state law. 
(g)  The city shall be obligated to determine if any liens are listed on the title of the vehicle and to notify the registered lien holders within three (3) business days of the date of impoundment by telephone followed by a certified letter. The notice shall include a description of the vehicle, the date of impoundment and the address where the impounded vehicle is located. A lienholder shall be entitled to the release of the vehicle as set forth in subsection (f) upon presentation of the original vehicle title evidencing the existence of the lien and written certification by the lien holder that the registered owner of the vehicle is in default on the indebtedness secured by the lien and that the lienholder is entitled to immediate possession. 
(h)  If any provisions of this section or the application of this section to any person, thing or circumstances, is held invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity shall not affect the provisions or application of this section can be given effect without the invalid provisions or applications and to this end, the provisions of this section and such amendments as may be made in the future are declared to be severable. 
(i)  Impoundment hearings. 
(1)  The owner or person entitled to possession of any motor vehicle which is removed or towed, pursuant to this section, shall be entitled to an immediate due process hearing, prior to paying any towing or storage fee concerning the motor vehicle. The chief of police or any supervisory officer of the police of the rank of police sergeant or above, designated by the chief of police, is designated and appointed as a hearing officer for the purpose of carrying out these requirements. Any owner or person entitled to possession of any motor vehicle, unless the right is waived, shall be provided an immediate due process hearing before such officer prior to being required to pay any such towing charge or storage fee. When the hearing officer shall determine at the hearing that the towing of the vehicle was in error, the vehicle shall be ordered immediately released and returned to the owner or person in possession without the payment of any charges or fees. 
(2)  Any person aggrieved by any decision of any hearing officer made pursuant to this section shall be entitled to a hearing before a municipal judge by filing notice wit the clerk of the municipal court within five (5) days from the date of any such decision. 
(3)  At any time an arrest or citation for violation of municipal ordinances is made in connection with the towing or impoundment of any motor vehicle by the police department, the municipal judge trying the case may also hear evidence concerning the impoundment, towing and storage of the motor vehicle. If the municipal judge shall determine, after a due process hearing, that the towing of the vehicle was in error, the municipal judge shall order the vehicle immediately released without the payment of any fees or charges, or if the fees or charges have already been paid, shall order the return of the fees to the person paying the fees. 
(Ord. No. 961, 3-3-08)  
Secs. 17-17—17-19. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PARKING 
 
Sec. 17-20. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
Handicapped parking areas: Those parking spaces designated for parking by persons so severely handicapped that such persons are unable to move from place to place without the aid of a mechanical device, wheelchair, walker, cane, crutch, invalid tricycle, or any similar device intended for and used by such persons. 
Operator: Any individual who shall operate a vehicle as the owner thereof, or as the agent, employee or permittee of the owner, or any person who is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
Park or parking: The standing of a vehicle, whether or not upon a street, otherwise than in obedience to traffic regulations, signs or signals, or an involuntary stopping of the vehicle by reason of causes beyond the control of the operator of the vehicle. 
Parking zones: Those areas of certain streets designated by the city and so marked and designated where parking of vehicles is limited or restricted. 
Street: Any public street, avenue, road, alley, highway, lane, path, or public place located in the city and established for the use of vehicles. 
Vehicle: Any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported upon a highway, except a device which is operated upon rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. 574, § 1, 1-21-85)  
Sec. 17-21. - Areas where parking is prohibited at all times. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or traffic-control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk. 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway. 
(3)  Within an intersection. 
(4)  Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant. 
(5)  On a crosswalk. 
(6)  Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection. 
(7)  Where there is no parking space marked or designated by lines painted or durably marked on curbing or the surface of the street, within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance or exit to any police station, fire station or rescue squad location and on the side of the street opposite the entrance or exit to any fire station, police station or rescue squad location within seventy-five (75) feet of that entrance or exit when properly posted. 
(8)  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave any vehicle on Gunter Avenue between the intersection of Lurleen B. Wallace Drive and Blount Avenue and Brown Street, and on Blount Avenue from Brown Street to the intersection of Blount Avenue and Gunter Avenue at the Harbor House Restaurant where there is no parking space marked or designated by lines painted or durably marked on curbing or surface of the street. 
(c)  No person shall park any motor vehicle at any time on the paved shoulder adjacent to the truck arrester ramp located in the city and more particularly described as beginning at the southernmost point of Hardin Road located on the east side of U.S. Highway No. 431 and designated as State Highway Marker No. 1-0.00 and running in a generally northwesterly direction one thousand (1,000) feet to State Marker No. 19+72. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle on the right-of-way located east of Sunset Drive from the intersection of Patterson Street and Sunset Drive and the intersection of Alabama Highway No. 69 (Henry Street) and Sunset Drive. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to park a motor vehicle or a mobile unit or trailer on the right-of-way located on Ringold Street from Hill Avenue to Jackson Avenue, both on the east and west side of Ringold Street. Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this subsection (e) shall be guilty of an offense, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined a sum not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) or be imprisoned for a term not exceeding ten (10) days or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(Ord. No. 545, § 1, 6-17-82; Ord. No. 660, § 1, 8-20-90; Ord. No. 716, §§ 1, 2, 6-5-95; Ord. No. 756A, §§ 1, 2, 3-17-97) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-137.  
Sec. 17-22. - Two-hour time limit parking. 
(a)  Except on Sundays or holidays, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle for a longer consecutive period of time than two (2) hours between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. in the following areas: 
(1)  On either side of Gunter Avenue from the intersection of Scott Street and Gunter Avenue to the intersection of Brown Street and Gunter Avenue. 
(2)  On either side of Blount Avenue from the intersection of Brown Street and Blount Avenue to the intersection of Taylor Street and Blount Avenue. 
(3)  On either side of Gunter Avenue from the intersection of Gilbreath Street to the intersection of Gunter Avenue and Henry Street and from the intersection of Gunter Avenue and Henry Street to the intersection of Henry Street and O'Brig Avenue. 
(4)  On either side of those portions of Taylor Street, Worth Street, and Court Street lying between Gunter Avenue and Blount Avenue; also those portions of Scott Street, Worth Street, and Ringold Street lying between Gunter Avenue and Hill Street, and on Taylor Street lying between Gunter Avenue and Old Town Street. 
(b)  Except on Sundays or holidays it shall be unlawful to park or leave any vehicle for a longer consecutive period of time than two (2) hours between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. in the city parking lot on the right side of Gunter Avenue at its intersection with Worth Street, more particularly described as follows: All that tract of land located in the city, being a portion of the east half of lot 1 of block "D" as shown on original survey of the city on file in the probate office of the county, and more particularly described as follows: Commencing at a point at the intersection of the southerly margin of Worth Street and the westerly margin of Broad Street and run thence in a southerly direction along the westerly margin of Broad Street a distance of one hundred ten (110) feet; thence in a westerly direction parallel to the southerly margin of Worth Street one hundred twenty (120) feet; thence in a northerly direction parallel to the westerly margin of Broad Street one hundred ten (110) feet to a point on the southerly margin of Worth Street; thence in an easterly direction along such southerly margin one hundred twenty (120) feet to the point of beginning; such property being a part of the same property conveyed to Gulf Oil Corporation, a Pennsylvania corporation and recorded in deed book 341, page 410, in the probate office of the county. 
(Ord. No. 574, § 2, 1-21-85)  
Sec. 17-23. - Handicapped parking. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave any vehicle in a stall or space designed for physically handicapped persons, if, immediately adjacent to and visible from such stall or space, there is posted a sign known as international wheelchair symbol or painted on the parking space a sign known as the international wheelchair symbol consisting of a profile view of a stylized wheelchair with occupant in white on a blue background or painted yellow on the parking space, unless the driver of the car is disabled. The penalty for the violation of this section shall be a payment of thirty-five dollars ($35.00). 
(Ord. No. 574, § 3, 1-21-85; Ord. No. 702, § III, 4-4-94)  
Sec. 17-24. - Violations—Punishment generally. 
Except as otherwise provided herein, any person who shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and shall be punished by a fine of not less than three dollars ($3.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00) to be imposed at the discretion of the court trying the case. 
(Ord. No. 574, 1-21-85)  
Sec. 17-25. - Same—Compromise of claim. 
(a)  Any person accused of a violation of a provision prohibiting parking a vehicle in a designated area or restricting the length of time a vehicle may be there parked, may settle and compromise a claim against such person for such illegal parking by paying to the municipality the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) within forty-eight (48) hours of the [time] such alleged offense was committed. A receipt shall be issued for all money so received and such money shall be promptly turned over to the city clerk treasurer to be used in the manner provided for the disposition of fines. 
The operator of the above-described vehicle may pay ten dollars ($10.00) at the city clerk's office within forty-eight (48) hours; or may appear at (date and time) _______ before the municipal judge for trial. 
This ticket is issued as a courtesy in lieu of an arrest. If the operator does not settle this claim or appear for trial, a warrant will be issued for violating this section.

(d)  This section shall not apply to persons parking a vehicle so as to obstruct the entrance or exit of any place where police or fire department apparatus or other emergency equipment is kept or housed, or so as to block an emergency entrance to a hospital; nor shall this article apply to any person charged with parking a vehicle so as to entirely obstruct traffic in any street or alley, or parking in such a way as to reduce traffic on an arterial street to one-way traffic only; nor to any person who refuses to move a vehicle illegally parked at the request of any member of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 574, § 5, 1-21-85; Ord. No. 702, § V, 4-4-94)

Sec. 17-26. - Same—Towing and towing charges. 
(a)  The police department, and all members thereof assigned to traffic duty, are hereby authorized to remove and tow away, or have removed and towed away, by commercial towing service, any car or other vehicle illegally parked in any place where such parked vehicle creates or constitutes a traffic hazard, blocks the use of a fire hydrant, or obstructs or may obstruct movement of any emergency vehicle. Any car or other vehicle parked in violation of section 17-21 or section 17-22 above may also be removed and towed away as herein provided. 
(b)  Cars so towed away for illegal parking shall be stored in a safe place and be restored to the owner or operator of such vehicle upon the payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) within twenty-four (24) hours after such vehicle was removed, plus two dollars ($2.00) for each additional twenty-four (24) hours or fraction thereof. 
(Ord. No. 574, § 4, 1-21-85; Ord. No. 702, § IV, 4-4-94) 
State Law reference— Officers authorized to remove vehicles, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-139.
